story:
Abelle Tsui, Alexander Graewert, Marie-Louise Stenild and James Bryce are taking part in a competitive 100km hike, raising money for Oxfam,
across some of Hong Kong’s most challenging terrain on 17-19
November. Please sponsor us. 

The Maclehose Trail is Hong Kong’s most demanding hiking route. The climbs and descents total several thousand metres. This 100km at hike speed means around 26-30 hours, and there’s a 48-hour cut-off. 

Oxfam Trailwalker is a fundraising sports event that runs in a range of
countries annually. This is the only one in Greater China. Over a
thousand teams are taking part.

Oxfam is a long-established global charity, working in the fields of
poverty alleviation and emergency relief.  Please help Oxfam and
sponsor us, whatever you find right.  Our target is
HKD25-30,000.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

The reason for creating this page is my passion for the charity, Oxfam. Oxfam support over 94 countries across the world, providing security, clean water and the tools and equipment needed for everyone to live a healthy and fulfilled life. Oxfam support those facing poverty and every penny raised will go directly to supporting those in need of Oxfam.

I am a Psychology student at Plymouth University and I have been given the amazing opportunity to potentially steward for Oxfam. This will mean I work at some of the most popular festivals throughout the summer and ensure everything runs smoothly. As well as becoming a steward, I wanted to help Oxfam further, by deciding to fundraise £200 I will be able to pay for 24 water wells to be drilled and built. This means clean water will be provided for over 20 communities, something we take for granted, but many desperately need.

Thank you so much for reading this and having a look at my page. Please consider donating and if you do donate, thank you so much!!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I’m on my mission to give aids to the people who are suffering and to make them live their best life in this world.

As we all know, majority of people globally struggles to survive for their life which includes suffered kids, oppressed women, and families living in extreme poverty. Refugees are fleeing away from their unstable countries to seek for asylum, they are in need for survival kits and health treatments. So, I’m planning to start a charity drive to help them as much as I possibly could. In order to execute this mission,

I’ll contribute 20% of what I’ve received from my graphic design service, to charity.


I believe in power of giving. “If you contribute more, you’ll get more in return.”


Please help me to reach my target and dig deep now. There will be lots of opportunities for you to support me and get the benefits at the same time.

Oxfam is one of the world’s largest charity organization and I’m very proud to be one of their supporter in contributing whatever I’ve got to make this world a better place to live. So, I would like to take this opportunity to personally invite anyone of you who are reading this post to contribute a part of your value for the cause. 

This is the least thing I could do to pay my contribution to the world. Even though my graphic design service could not help directly in terms giving aid or manpower, but I’ve always wanted to contribute some portion of my services for charity. So, this is my way to be the part of making others living their best life in this world. My goal is to raise as much as possible for the charity drive by raising my service standards to the best quality as possible.

What inspires me to do the charity drive is by looking inspiring from big entrepreneurs out there giving away their life and money to help others. Bill Gates is one of the people I am inspired by, whom donated most of his wealth for charity reasons around the globe. I do realize that I’m not that so called a big company to donate most of my wealth to charity. But I believe that with every small step I’ve made, I could make a difference in someone’s life.

I chose Oxfam as my charity platform because they are doing a great job on giving aids to the needs out there in all around the world. Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal – an end to poverty for everyone. I believe on what they believed, “In a world rich in resources, poverty isn’t inevitable.” I feel that I’m not the one whom need the most from the resources, so I think I should give my part to someone who need it the most. Oxfam believe that everyone should be able to eat, drink, earn and learn as much as we do. 

Through Oxfam and their partners, 4.3 million people got access to clean water, 2 million people got food, cash or vouchers to survive a crisis, and 1.7 million women were supported to exercise their rights. They couldn't have done it without someone like us. 

On average for every £1 donated to Oxfam, they invest 84p on their humanitarian, development and campaigning work. They invest 8p to raise further funds, and they invest 8p on support and running costs such as paying the salaries of staff who work all year round to deliver their work and who ensure they are effective and accountable.

To conclude and to mention it again, the idea behind the charity drive is to cut off 20% from every income I’ve received from my graphic design service and donating them to charity. So, obviously, the more I get, the more I will give in return and more people I could contribute to. This is my goal. All donation will go straight to my profile at JustGiving.com and will be donated to Oxfam. 

Thank you for all you support!

Regards,
Azri Omar

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Collectively we have decided to take part in the Trailwalker 2018 event. This is a 100km foot race through the South Downs National Park using trails and dirt tracks but also must be completed in under 30 hours. This is going to be an enormous challenge for us all but we are looking forward to having the opportunity to make a difference in whatever way we can. We will all be raising money for Oxfam, who are actively trying to reduce poverty, hunger and social injustice on a global scale. We have all been fortunate enough to have been put in a position where we can strive towards achieving our dreams in a sporting and academic capacity, however not everyone is this fortunate. We believe that everyone everywhere, should have the right to reach their potential and that poverty should not be a limiting factor in determining the level of success people can achieve, but unfortunately it is. By donating, you will not only be motivating us to run/walk/crawl 100km, you will be directly working to combat injustice and inequality on a globe scale.

Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.


We are joining the ‘Dream challenges’ team in November in a 5-day trek in Jordan from the Dead Sea to Petra to raise money for Oxfam.

The trek will be tough, testing our determination and stamina. The ascent to the Jordan's Black Mountain (1350m) will be challenging; the large communal Bedouin tents we will sleep in on the cold desert nights (temperature in the desert can drop below freezing!) will be far from luxurious but we are sure that the beautiful views of the Dead Sea, Petra and the desert canyons will make up for it! 


We have been working on increasing our fitness level to prepare for this. We have recently done some long treks in the Peak District and survived a 2-week walking holiday in Northern Ireland this summer.

We’ll be kept going by the knowledge that the money we are raising is going to have a big impact in the lives of many people. Oxfam works in over 90 countries, fighting poverty by responding to emergencies, through development projects and campaigns to tackle the root
causes.

We hope you will join us in this adventure and support our challenge.

The trek is self-funded; all money donated will be sent directly
to the charity. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hey everyone 

Thanks for visiting our Just Giving page! We are a team of four women who are willing to undertake the endurance of the 100K Oxfam TrailWalker Challenge through the South Downs from the Queen Elizabeth County Park in Hampshire, starting at 6am on the 14 July to trek day and night non-stop until we reach Brighton! The event is timed and we plan to finish in sub-24 hours so we can be in Brighton for breakfast! 

This will be the ultimate challenge for our team as we have never undergone an ultra before! Made up of runners, hikers, trailwalkers and cyclists, though our outdoor activity styles are different we all share a love of a challenge and a passion for life. This challenge will definitely be our toughest to date but we are excited to be part of it and work to become Trailwalker Legends!! To hike, walk and run solid for 24 hours will test us to our limits of mental and physical strength. The route was set by The Gurka Signals over 30 years ago as the ultimate test of teamwork and endurance for new recruits with a total ascent of 2,500m - the equivalent of Ben Nevis and Snowdonia combined - this will be no walk in the park. To achieve this challenge we will be training for months to make sure we are Trailwalker fit and to make you all an Oxfam proud!

For more information about the challenge check out Oxfam's website https://www.oxfam.org.uk/Trailwalker. We aim to raise a minumum of £1400 which will provide live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterbourne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap. £1650 would provide safe drinking water for 1,650 people. Clean water is an essential for life and should be a basic human right. Please help us make that happen. 

Thank you 

Hannah, Louise, Carrie and Tilly

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I grew up in Mexico City and my family still live there. As you will know, Mexico has now been hit by three devastating earthquakes in recent weeks which killed more than 250 people and injured 700 more.

I am blessed to be able to say that all my close family and friends are safe, however it wasn’t until they described to me the current situation that I realised the scale of the devastation suffered by my home city and country.

Thousands of families have lost their homes including friends of my mum, but the most affected people are those in the most deprived communities who have lost everything and are in desperate need of help.

A lot of my friends and relatives have been actively providing support and volunteering around the city and it makes me sad to be so far away at this time and not being able to be there to do my bit. That is why I decided to start a fund and give up some of my time over the next three months to raise money. I have chosen to raise money for Oxfam who have created a dedicated ‘Earthquake in Mexico’ fund, which will be 100% used for support services and relief and recovery efforts for affected areas.

We are so lucky to live in a country where we are safe from natural disasters like those recently seen in Mexico and in the Caribbean, as well as to benefit from the basic safety net provided by the welfare state.

If you can spare a bit money and would like to donate through my just giving page then I will be very grateful. If you would like to find out a bit more or would like to help me with my fundraising endeavors I’d love to hear from you.

Many thanks Maribel

story:
Many thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On Saturday, 14th July 2018 I will be setting out to complete 100 km across the South Downs Way in two teams of four.  Testudinidae britannica A and Testudinidae britannica B are both teams of mixed ability and experience but with the single-minded determination to walk, jog and run the course together in under 30 hours.

Oxfam Trailwalker 2018 is a team endurance event, starting at Queen Elizabeth Country Park, near Petersfield, along the South Downs Way to the finish line at Brighton Racecourse.

Organised by Oxfam GB and the Queen's Gurkha Signals, money raised will support both the work of Oxfam as well as the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
The idea of this page is to enable you to donate excess credit from your PAYG mobile phone account to an excellent cause. You can do this by texting OXFA70 £n to 70070, where n is 1,2,3,4,5, or 10. So to donate £10, you'd text OXFA70 £10 to 70070.

You'll receive an acknowledgement text which includes a link so that taxpayers can Gift Aid their donation. You'll also be offered a choice between anonymity and having your contact details passed on. Please choose anonymity - I don't want to know who is donating, I just want you to donate to my chosen cause!

100% of text donations and of any Gift Aid goes to the charity. It isn't restricted to PAYG; for Pay Monthly, the donation is added to your next invoice. It is open to users of all UK mobile networks, and the admin is done by JustTextGiving. 

You can also donate by card using the purple 'Donate' link on this page if you prefer, and a small service fee is deducted from your donation.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Starting on the 1st March I'm going to be giving up alcohol for at least a month. Possibly longer! I'm a big fan of beer so this is a huge thing for me! I'll admit that it's not totally for selfless reasons. I'd like to be a bit more healthy and not spend my money on beer all the time, but I thought why not make it a thing and raise some money for Oxfam in the process!

Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn't inevitable. In just 15 years, extreme poverty has been halved. 15 more years and we can end it for good.

Being a volunteer of Oxfam for a number of years now they were the obvious choice as I'm fully aware of the amazing work they do for people in extreme poverty. Sponsor me today and 82p of every pound you donate goes goes directly to emergency, development and campaigning work.

It would be amazing to raise at least 200 pounds as this would pay: -
To train 4 family's to grow their own food or,
For 320 mosquito nets for children or,
To drill 24 wells for clean safe drinking water.

Please donate as little or as much as you can afford, thank you.

Help Families Worldwide To Overcome Disaster

Just £5 can help provide clean water for a family

£25 could help families replant crops so they can start earning again

£50 could help provide the materials to build a flood proof house

Every £1 you donate is doubled by the UK Government

Thank you for any donation, however small, because it can make a difference!

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Oxfam need our help to reach 500,000 people affected by Typhoon Haiyan.

Typhoon Haiyan, one of the strongest storms ever recorded, has struck the Philippines. Oxfam is ready to deploy water and sanitation materials to those affected.

Rapid assessment teams are on the ground to provide urgent emergency supplies and shelter on the islands of Samar, Leyte and Cebu where near-total devastation is reported.

Donate now to help Oxfam reach people with life-saving aid.

Every penny and pound really does count. £27 could provide 10 Oxfam buckets to help provide clean water. £50 could provide 100 emergency health kits.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story: This year I helped organise the Cambridge Oxfam walk. I was Route co-ordinator- I walked all 26 miles of the route, prepared the maps, route instructions, instructions for marshals etc over about 7 months in the run-up to the  walk. On the day I was Event Co-ordinator, liaising with the rest of the team to ensure everything happened at the right time, answering questions and generally ensuring the event ran smoothly. We are hoping to raise £30,000, please help us to achieve that target. All money raised by this event goes to Oxfam's Disaster Fund.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Our names are Dylan, Henry and Sam. We are all seven years old in year three and we live in Christchurch in Dorset. 

We were very upset by the fact that 93,000 people have died in the Syrian civil war and wanted to do something to help. We kept on watching it on the news and although we know this isn't going to happen to us we did imagine what it would be like if 93,000 of us died or if we or our families had to run away from our house and leave our things.

So me Henry and Sam decided to do a fun run in October. We are doing lots of training so we get really good at running. We want to try to raise £50 each.

What's happening in Syria is terrible and the more people who know about it the better as we want to show the people of Syria that we have not forgotten about them and care about what is happening.

We want to stop bad injuries and deaths and want to raise the money to get a tent to help people and maybe help them to buy a house. We think Oxfam will help make things a bit better.

So we want to get people to sponsor us.

The Fun Run will take place between Southbourne and Bournemouth Pier in October half term. My little brother Rufus who is 6 will ride on his bike with us to help encourage us to keep on going too. Lily who is Henry's little sister will also ride along with us too. 

 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page, I would like to share our journey and story with you all.

Our beautiful mummy’s chapter has sadly come to an end on earth, she went to sleep peacefully and beautifully on 26th January 2017. Her soul was returned to heaven to embrace her new journey as angel.

She had so much love and joy to give - she was selfless, courageous, strong, determined, kind and thoughtful. She has taught us so much about what it truly means to be a family and shown us the importance of loving the people that you meet in your life; be it your spouse, your children, your friends or a stranger in time of need. Her heart lives on through all of us and all those who have ever known her. 

In her final moments, we were with her every step of the way. She used all her strength to open her eyes and looked at us individually to say "I love you" and then a final "I love you all". She told us that she was going to sleep and tomorrow will be a better day.

She fought so hard and so well - sometimes things aren't meant to be and it’s ok because we’ve learnt to let her be free from the body that she was trapped in. Her last eye contacts was fixated on my dad and she used such energy to say "I love you" - A selfless act.

We are fundraising for our mummy’s favourite charity, she used to say the more charitable and kindness you can show and act on, one day you will return to the heavens above as an angel.

I will leave you with her words that she used to say to me: "It's ok to have good days and it's ok to have bad days - you're only human! 

In the end what pulls you through the tough times is the power of the mind. Take a chance even if the chances are slim it's still a chance, as long as you believe it you can do it, it will happen. Love your children, love your spouse, be kind to others, be kind to yourself. 

Even when the time does come, face it with bravery and dignity but don't face it alone. You're only going to sleep and if you're not afraid of going to sleep you're not afraid of anything else. 

This is not dying, this is just a beginning to a new journey and make every moment that you have a precious one too, think of happier times don't look back with sorrow and continue fighting to the very end. Stay in the moment, take one step and one day at a time and always try your best, never live a moment of regret."

Sleep well my gracious angel, I love you so much and I'm so proud of you - we all are. Your gorgeous smile and kind heart will always be in our memories. Love you mummy. Xxx

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
GBI Cycle Challenge - Luxembourg to Dusseldorf - DONE!

On 3rd July 2013, I took part in a cycling challenge from Luxembourg to Dusseldorf covering 402km over 3 days (Luxembourg, Belgium and Germany)

This is my longest bike challenge so far and did it to support Oxfam UK (Syria Crisis Appeal).

It was an amazing experience/ journey… Great views, New friends and raised money for Charity.

I can’t wait to do it again next year!!!

If anyone wants to join in, then the challenge will be to cycle from Budapest to Munich..

It’s a long way - but you will not regret it!

HUGE THANKS to everyone who has alread supported me..

You can still donate online or by texting SHEZ48 £10 (or whatever amount you like) to 70070. It's free, easy to set up and every penny goes to charity!

owner: Melinda Warby - Tyneside Rejects and the Lady
story:
Thanks very much for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page! Mug shots above...

In a moment of madness we all agreed to take part in Trailwalker 2018 for Oxfam and The Gurkhas Trust.  We will join many others between the 13-15th July 2018 to walk across the South Downs starting in Queen Elizabeth Country Park (near Petersfield, Hampshire) and ending on Brighton Race Course. All in under 30 hours.

Steve Perrins, Graeme Fletcher and James Mortimer are all fine, athletic specimens, ex-army and if it wasn't for me (and Steve's knees), I am sure they would be marching round in no time!  Sorry lads!

For my part, this is the first time that I have ever attempted anything like this. Training has begun in earnest and to save the ears of my fellow team members from my grumbles and groans on the way round, I will be putting a vast "Rocky training" play list together!

Now for the dough.... there will be many of you I am sure who would pay good money to see the Tyneside Rejects and the Lady go through this pain. I am pretty sure I won't be looking much like a lady by the end of it! Thankfully it will be dark!  ANY donations that you are able to give will be gratefully received and hugely appreciated.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.


Thank you all in advance for your generosity.

From

Steve, James, Graeme and Melinda (aka.. the Tyneside Rejects and the Lady)

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Each Trailwalker team pledges to raise £1,400 for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust as part of their challenge. Broken down between all 4 walking team members, this works out at just £350 per person!

The money will be used for many different causes such as providing live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterbourne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap. It will also be used to fund a Gurkha Welfare Trust nurse for six months, helping to provide medical aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities and much much more. 

Please help us smash this target and pledge what you can. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Each Trailwalker team pledges to raise £1,400 for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust as part of their challenge. Broken down between all 4 walking team members, this works out at just £350 per person!

The money will be used for many different causes such as providing live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterbourne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap. It will also be used to fund a Gurkha Welfare Trust nurse for six months, helping to provide medical aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities and much much more.

Please help us smash this target and pledge what you can.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Oxjam Wakefield music festival is coming in October 2018!

Donate to help make a charity DIY local music festival possible, all money raised will be donated to Oxfam to support the fight against poverty worldwide. 

The multi-venue festival will take place in Wakefield city centre bringing you an eclectic mix of the best local music and art. Follow us on Social media for updates and find tickets for the event at wegottickets.com

Around the globe, Oxfam works to find practical, innovative ways for people to lift themselves out of poverty and thrive. We save lives and help rebuild livelihoods when crisis strikes. And we campaign so that the voices of the poor influence the local and global decisions that affect them.

We hope to see you at the festival!

WANT TO GET INVOLVED? 

Send us an email oxjamwakefield2018@gmail if you are interested in volunteering, fundraising or if you have any creative ideas!

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
The devastating earthquakes and after shocks which have hit in Nepal in the last few weeks have left 8000 dead, 14000 injured, over 700,000 homeless and 8 million affected. Already a country battling poverty, Nepal is suffering immensly as a result. 

Although several thousand miles away, each and every one of us is still able to help out. For SURC , Nepal is a country close to many of our members adventuring hearts and so we've decided to get fundraising.

What is happening?
 
SURC (Southampton University Road Cycling club) are putting on 48-hour non-strop rollathon in support the Oxfam's Nepal Appeal to try and cycle the equivalent distance of Southampton to Kathmandu.  It’s taking place on 29-31st May on Campus.  We'll keep 8 sets of rollers constantly going by alternating riders with the intention of riding this massive distance. There will be music, lights, a big crowd and food/drinks to keep everyone going through the nights.

How can I get involved?

As you can imagine, SURC will need lots of people for this mammoth task, that is where you come in. If you can give just an hour of your time over the weekend that would be amazing. If you are free and around, I urge you to take part. The sign-up is here https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1eaWQQpZI98lyPqFtiZ6USzrJufIaDqeLTUIbv4suE9Y/viewform?usp=send_form.

If you can't make the weekend, then we'd love if it you wanted to make a donation directly to Oxfam through this website.

Thank you for you support.

charity.name: Oxfam
eventName: A Night With Sara Shahidi And Friends
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page for "A Night With Sara Shahidi And Friends".

Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn't inevitable. In just 15 years, extreme poverty has been halved. 15 more years and we can end it for good.

Oxfam supports refugees by helping to provide life saving hygiene kits to stop the spread of disease, provide families with clean drinking water and help to build toilet and washing facilities for families made homeless. In Syria, Jordan and Lebanon, Oxfam provides life-saving clean water, sanitation and vital support for families who have lost everything.  In Greece, Italy, Serbia and Macedonia Oxfam provides water, food, clothes and personal hygiene kits, as well as longer term psychological and legal support. And around the world, Oxfam is making sure that people fleeing conflict have the life-saving essentials they need.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
We are the Sir John Lawes School Oxfam Youth Action Group, a group of young people from ages 11 to 18 who campaign, fundraise and raise awareness for Oxfam. We are united by our desire to bring about social justice and help those who are suffering in the world.

Our current focus is on South Sudan, where fierce fighting has forced more than a million people from their homes. Oxfam has already reached 261,000 people at several locations across South Sudan with food, clean water, sanitation, and hygiene materials and training. They urgently need help from people like us to be able to offer assistance to more people and prevent the crisis from turning into a catastrophe.

We chose this project to work on as South Sudan is something of an unseen crisis, which isn't usually prominent in the media, and which many people in our school and the wider community may never have heard of before. As such, we set up a 'mock refugee camp' at our school one lunchtime to raise awareness amongst the student body.

We will be camping for the night at school, and would massively appreciate any donations, however big or small, that you are able to give. Together we really can make a difference.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thank you.

Susi, Dottie, Jack, Charlotte, Chloe, Kyran, Zoe, Miriam, Polly, Louis, Aimie, Meg, Lauren, Ellen, Lena and Cameron- the SJL Oxfam Youth Action Group

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Oxjam is a festival like no other. It’s a new type of festival.

Not only is it the UK’s largest grassroots music festival, it’s also dedicated to eradicating poverty around the world, with all money raised going to Oxfam. Now that’s something we can all get behind.

Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn’t inevitable. Since the Festival’s inception more than 60,000 musicians have played to an audience of 1.5 million people, raising £2.8 million to support Oxfam’s vital work.

By supporting Oxjam then, you are also supporting your community and your local independent music venues, you’re providing a platform for up and coming musical talent and you are raising money to fight poverty worldwide.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Today (February 12), the Disaster Emergency Committee has said that it's members would not be not be offering help to those affected by the recent floods in the UK. See Daily Express article.

As a result, Oxfam's Twitter and Facebook have been overwhelmed with seemingly outraged comments by users who say they will no longer donate to Oxfam.

We feel it is important to show Oxfam that this view definitely isn't shared by all, that we continue to support their work, and that they have made the right decision to put their resources where they are most needed -- which is why we have created this fundraising campaign!

OxJam Salisbury 2018 is a grassroots music festival brought together by and for the local community. We aim to support independent venues, artists and businesses by bringing music lovers of all kind together behind a global cause - eliminating extreme poverty, for good.

Raising funds on behalf of Oxfam, OxJam Salisbury will be a multi-venue festival in a day this October, involving many independent venues and local artists. 

Throughout the summer and autumn we will be putting on events across the city to both support the local events industry and businesses as well raise funds for an amazing cause - fighting poverty and equality. 

Find out more about the events and activities you can get involved in by following @OxJamSalisbury on Instagram and Facebook.

No doubt you're all starting to think about what Christmas presents you're going to buy for friends and family this year - we're asking that as you take a little time to think about those less fortunate who won't be receiving as many, if any, presents under the tree. As part of the Unilever ETS team we are giving something back to this Christmas. On the 7th December we are taking over the Oxfam Ealing Broadway store in London to raise as much money as possible for this wonderful charity. To increase our fundraising, we have set-up this Just Giving page so anyone can donate to the cause. 

Anything you can spare will be greatly appreciated - even if it means spending £1 less on buying everyone a Christmas present this year.

story:
I'm excited to be running the London Marathon in 2018 as part of #TeamOxfam. I decided I wanted to have run the marathon a few years ago but realised that I'll need to actually run it for this to be true...!
It's great to have the opportunity to raise money for such a brilliant cause and I'm extremely grateful for all contributions.

Oxfam is an amazing charity that helps fight poverty around the world.  They get help to people that need it; whether it's an emergency helping with food and water, or one of their long term projects promoting education and schemes that help communities help themselves.  It's a great motivation for me over months of training, and on race day, to know that the relatively small commitment from me will have contributed to helping those that really need it.


Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page it really means a lot to us. Oxjam Sowerby Bridge Festival is a large community project involving as much of the town as we can! It's run entirely by volunteers as part of the UK's largest grassroots music festival. 

In October we are holding a multi-venue music festival in the town. Not to mention as many fun fundraising events as we can along the way. Sowerby Bridge is a great town with a rich music history, you should really come and visit sometime! We aim to involve as much of the community as possible to raise funds for Oxfams life saving work. Local Music. Global Impact. 

We invite you to come down and enjoy the town with us but if you can't please donate. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

May 7th will be my first triathlon. It's only a 'mini' one, or 'sprint triathlon' as the pro would say  (400m swim, 21k cycle, 5k run).  But it's a challenge for me.  I'm glad to say it's one that my middle son, Alex, and his friend Maddie, are joining in on too.

I'm raising funds for Oxfam because I know what good work they do, and that now more than ever funds are needed.  

If you can sponsor anything at all that is truly welcome.  If you instead sign up as a regular supporter of Oxfam, or decide to increase you current subscription, then Ashley Insight will put £20 sponsorship onto this tab for you.  https://www.oxfam.org.uk/donate 

Oxfam has been very honest that what happened in Haiti was awful, and wrong. And that thousands of supporters cancelled their subscriptions in disgust.  But there have also been a smaller band of people signing up for the first time or raising their contribution to Oxfam, because they perceive one organisation being hugely vilified.  They know that problems run deep in society and across the sector, and one organisation cannot be held responsible alone.   I've worked inside Oxfam for a year now, and I see how seriously gender justice is taken. And will be even more central going forward.  The irony is that Oxfam is a rare organisation that tries to challenge the deep-rooted barriers women face, such as discriminatory attitudes and violence.  I've also seen how transparency feeds newspaper headlines: Oxfam has been reporting safeguarding claims in the annual report for some years already.  

Next time around, I will revert to raising funds for deafness or other causes outside of my day job, but this year is a time for solidarity with Oxfam and the people it is helping day by day.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Stourport High School has a long history of supporting worthy causes. Oxfam is just such an example and this year has launched a Nepal Appeal.

Nepal has recently been hit by two massive earthquakes and a landslide. It is a poor country with limited resources. We,as a country, have strong links with Nepal through our military association with the Gurkhas and as such the country needs our help.

On the 10th July students will be undertaking several sessions on Oxfam, the Gurkhas and Trailwalker (a charitable event set up to raise money for the Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam). This will raise awareness and hopefully inspire students to get involved along with raising awareness of the wider world around them.

Any donation, large or small, will massively help us to reach our target.

Thanks in advance.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. 

The team are signed up for another Trailwalker challenge, a100km walk over the South Downs which we are aiming to complete this year in under 22 hours. Last year we were one of the oldest (combined age) teams in the competition.

We are walking to raise money for Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust. 

Oxfam have had a challenging year. But Oxfam's work is keeping people alive who would otherwise die. Oxfam uses our money to support 65 million people around the world - many of them children - who have had to flee their homes as a result of conflict and are often living in desperate conditions in camps or in the open. Your donation will make a real and rapid difference to people who are suffering badly.

We promise to suffer badly also, but in a very different way, as our penance for asking you once again for your support! All the money goes to Oxfam. None of it goes towards the costs of organising the challlenge which we have paid for through our entry fees.

If you feel able to support us - brilliant and thank you.

story:
Oxfam Oxy-Gym has been set up for people who love a gym challenge or who just love challenges. The idea is to raise money through sports.

The Press Up is one of the best Chest, Shoulders and Arm building move's around, it show's both strength and endurance.

The Challenge
Start standing then go into the press up position, do one press up, then stand. Then back into the press up position, do two press ups and stand. Then back into the press up position and do three press ups and then on until failure. How many press ups can you get up to?

Nominate 3 people after the challenge, put your challenge on FaceBook for everyone to see.

Text OGPU 83 to 70070 to donate £3 now.

All money raised will go to Oxfam's Water and Sanitation projects.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
We are 4 friends who accepted a challenge to walk 100km (63 miles) in under 30 hours. This challenge will take place on July 14th-15th, starting at Queen Elizabeth Park, The New Forest & ending at Brighton Racecourse.



We've been training hard - we have suffered blisters, hip pain, knee pain, extreme hunger, rain, scary night walks, mastering farm gates (Kinga) - mastering climbing them (Nicky) but it's all been fun and preparing us for this epic challenge...100km in one day....ahhhhh



The event is organised by Oxfam - raising money to reduce poverty.  We aim to raise £3000 which will help to start 12 farms / small holdings for families.  Providing, food, education, an income & a future for generations to come. 



If you would like to support us please donate via this page.  We will also be running fundraising events in the coming months so keep your eyes peeled for those on our FB or Insta pages.



Thanks for your support - it will make the blisters, painful knees & hips worth it!



Lots of love N,H,K & R x x x x x

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Scrambled Legs will be taking on the Trailwalk challenge of walking 100K (60 miles) in 30 hours  on 14th and 15th July. We start the walk at the Queen Elizabeth Country Park in Portsmouth, walking along the South Downs Way to the finish line at Brighton Racecourse. The main objective for taking on this challenge is to raise essential funds for charity, but also for other reasons too - personal challenges, camaraderie, fond memories and endurance training. There will probably be a few occasions along the walk we will want to forget! 

We have a tough 15 week training programme leading up to the main event, and need to ready to walk 100K, assisted by our support crew, who will meet us at each check point and be responsible for keeping us physically and emotionally upbeat throughout the 30 hours! 

We are raising money and awareness for Oxfam UK and the Gurkha Welfare Trust. Oxfam is a global movement of people, all working together for one goal - an end to poverty for everyone. The Gurkha Welfare Trust provides financial, medical and development aid to ex-Gurkha servicemen and their communities in Nepal.

You will be able to track the progress of Scrambled Legs throughout the 30 hours, and we are aiming to finish the event in 27 hours. I am sure you will appreciate this challenge is going to be the toughest any of us have done. We start at 10am Saturday morning and hopefully will be complete by 1pm on the Sunday, walking through the night, with tight target times at each check point to enable us to continue the event in the maximum time allowed of 30 hours, with no sleep!

Please consider how you can support us, by donating and sharing our journey with your friends and contacts on social media.

Thanks in anticipation 

Cheryl, Martina, Eric and Laura - Scrambled Legs 

Support crew: Tanya Norris, Andy Hunter, Liz Kapusta and Claire/Niamh Hunter

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hello folks,

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Me and my friends - colleagues - are taking the Trailwalker challenge once again this year. It is a 100km walk across rolling hills of South Downs in England which has to be completed within maximum 30 hours. We are going to walk non-stop through the night, with just short breaks, and no matter the weather conditions are. Last year it took us amazing 27 hours and 27 minutes to complete the walk, and this year we aim to be even better.

If you think it's a brave and challenging thing to do....maybe something you don't think you could do yourself, and if you perhaps admire our decision and determination, please support our team ''Shovel Monkeys'' and donate ANY amount of money. ANYTHING is highly appreciated and EVERYTHING goes to support the Ghurkas in Nepal.

You can also easily donate via TEXT MESSAGE - just send a text SHOV81 £5 to number 70070.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
As a part time Johnny Vegas look-alike who is somewhat dyspraxic, it's not an exaggeration to say that sport can be quite a trying thing for me – any level of fitness I have derives from chasing hard after a football having failed to control it in the first place. Without this motivation, I struggle to work up a sweat.

I'm going to be running the Southampton half marathon on Sunday the 22nd of April 2018. Quite the challenge as I've never even run a formal 5k.

I'm running for Oxfam, a charity I work for and feel a gratitude towards. There are almost too many reasons to list here. Mostly, I'm grateful for being surrounded by conscientious, music-obsessed and kind volunteers giving their time to help people in need.
If friends and family would rather donate to an alternative charity (as so many have already supported Oxfam in numerous ways), I'd welcome alternative contributions to Alzheimer's Research UK and Cancer Research UK in particular

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Since spring 2017 a staggering 18.8 million - 70% of Yemen's population - are suffering from food insecurity and acute malnutrition. 

The famine is being compounded by Yemen facing the world’s worst ever recorded cholera outbreak, which has spread across the war-ravaged country.  More than 1 million cases have been reported and over 2,200 people have died since the start of the epidemic.

I will be working with Oxfam GB to help raise money for delivering aid for the people in Yemen. Between July 22nd - 23rd 2018, I will be participating in a '40 hour famine' - no food and water for 40 hours. 

I kindly ask all who are willing to support me to donate what you can. Millions of Yemenis are in desperate need of help, but your donations can help bring food and water to families in crisis. 

Thank you!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
So I've gone mad.... and I'm going to run a marathon. 26.2 miles. For anyone who truly knows me, will know how far out of my comfort zone this really is. I really wanted a personal challenge, and after seeing a couple of my close friends and family members complete this incredible achievement it gave me the push to actually apply. Then I got a place coupled with an opportunity to raise some money for a great charity along the way. After a few weeks of panicking I've finally come to terms with the journey ahead and the amount I'm going to run . I know the road is going to be long but it's nothing compared to what some people experience and the real poverty they live each day.

When applying I decided I wanted to run for a charity as well take my chances with a ballot place. I thought hard about what difference I wanted to make with the funds I would raise. Oxfam really help those in need, across the whole globe.

Whilst we all know the aim of the game for Oxfam: to tackle global poverty, make sure people can get clean water to drink and decent sanitation. Provide help for people to get food and the essentials they need to survive and ensure the most vulnerable are kept safe from harm.

How Oxfam actually do it is not that widely known. The quote below shows that not all of the donations go on head office costs and they are making a difference in the world.

"On average for every £1 received by Oxfam, we invest 82p on our humanitarian, development and campaigning work. We invest 8p to raise further funds, and we invest 10p on support and running costs such as paying the salaries of staff who work all year round to deliver our work and who ensure we are effective and accountable. (These figures are taken from Oxfam GB's 2016/17 Annual Report.)"

Here is what your donation could buy:

A donation of £5 could pay for a goat for two families.

£16 can could support a survivor of sexual violence to receive training and guidance in coping with her experiences and understanding her rights in Iraq.

£20 can provide two toilets

£35 can provide one person with access to clean safe water

All of these things we take for granted on a daily basis.

So please- give generously because this is an amazing charity. And come and see me on race day- any support is gratefully received.


Jess



Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Oxfam
eventName: Putting our heads together for Syria!
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our Oxfam JustGiving page.

Jay and I decided that Syrian refugees needed more help, obviously! What's going on in Syria is both horrific and totally unacceptable. No one deserves to have to flee for their lives, only to then find themselves stuck in 3rd world conditions because other countries don't know what to do with them. We chose UNICEF and Oxfam as they both have a great track records for helping refugees and those in crisis. If we raise enough on this Oxfam page and our UNICEF page, as a thank you and just for a little fun, WE'LL SHAVE OUR HEADS!!!

Thanks for the support :) please share! 

Lots of love, 

Marchie and Cheshire xx

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I have come a long way since my first attempt at training in early January this year – it was cold and raining, I was hopelessly unfit after Christmas holiday excess and I think I spent more time walking than running. Since then I have added a cumulative 290 miles to my training total, and whilst I think Keitany can probably sleep easy in the knowledge I shall not be challenging the women's record she set in London in 2017, I am feeling moderately more confident about the prospect of at least finishing my first marathon.

I am raising money for Oxfam, which works in over 90 developing countries providing disaster relief and development aid particularly around themes of water, women, work and inequality. The charity has had some sad recent governance failures, but I hope you feel, like me, that this needn't mean losing sight of the work it does to support the lives of over 11 million people worldwide.

Thank you so much for all your support and tolerance for my banging on about running for the last few months, and I look forward to catching up on the other side.

CB xxx

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
We're mad, getting older, but still able and most of all, we like a challenge. Back in December some mad fool had the idea to suggest to his mates that we all take part in the Oxfam Trailwalker 100KM challenge.

Trailwalker is the ultimate team endurance event. 'The challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours in a team of four, with a support crew of two members to help you get to the finish line.

We are entering two teams. 

"Brighton or Bust" sees a total Romsey contingent of Peter "Chubb" Robinson, John Fahey, Simon Haythornthwaite and Mark Hutchings. 

"Four Walkers & a Funeral' which includes Rod Clark, Chris Lloyd-Tunstall, Ian Davies and Mark Fower. 

Such an extreme challenge cannot be completed without a Support Team. We owe great thanks to our very own Kings of Logistics, Richard Hughes, Mike Feast and Tony Godleman.

Starting at Queen Elizabeth Country Park near Petersfield, the Trailwalker route will take us along the South Downs Way to the finish line at Brighton Racecourse at which point we will be hungry enough to eat our own walking socks, hallucinating due to lack of sleep not to mention a 30 hour period without visiting a pub. Yes, it's a challenge for us middle-aged men of Hampshire.

Each team needs to raise £1400 in order to be considered worthy of this challenge, and to get a T-shirt of course ; )

If any Business owners out there would like to donate by company cheque (do they still exist?) then get in touch and I'll give you the necessary details.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Love you all and thank you for your support !

Oxfam Trailwalker 13 - 15 July 2018

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hi Everyone,

Lets talk about a challenge!

On 15th July 2018, myself and three team mates will be walking 100 Kilometers to raise money and awareness for Oxfam UK and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. The Oxfam Trailwalker begins at Queen Elizabeth Country Park passes through stunning but challenging terrain of South Downs National Park and finishes at Brighton Racecourse.

Teams of four enter this event and have 30 hours to walk or run the 100 km trail, although our team is hoping to finish within 20 hours. It’s very likely that we’ll walk through the night (with little or no sleep) until the end. The event raises vital funds for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. The Gurkha welfare trust is a charity that provides financial, medical and community aid to ex-Gurkha servicemen and their communities in Nepal.

My team "GasPanic" is hoping to raise funds to help some of the world’s poorest people. Our fundraising campaign will also enable Oxfam to respond immediately to emergencies around the world, as well as to fight poverty at its roots by campaigning against injustice and empowering people with life-changing projects.

My Trailwalker team members and I will be going the distance and we hope that you can support us in this massive challenge. Please consider how you may be able to get behind us, either by donating us or sharing our journey with your contacts in social media. If you would like to support us then please find more information about our goals and activities on this page and where to donate for this good cause.

100 km is a long way to walk! But putting ourselves through months of intense training will be worth it for the impact our fundraising has on others through Oxfam & The Gurkha Welfare trust. Your support is what will take me and my teammates over that finish line.

We ask you to please give generously and consider that your donation will make a real difference.

Thank you!

Yogen

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
On 15th April I will be running Brighton marathon in memory of my mum, who passed away last April. Shortly before she died I asked her to choose a charity that she would like me to run Brighton for this year, knowing she would not be here to see it. 

My mum, apart from being generally amazing, was a big supporter of my running and loved to come and cheer me on, patiently waiting on the sidelines with a bottle of water for me. Sadly this year she will not be there cheering at mile 16. 

The charity she chose has had some difficulties recently, but I believe she would want me to stick by them and focus on the good work that they have done and hope that they can make the changes that are obviously required. 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
It's been a lifelong ambition to run a marathon, so with the age of 30 rapidly approaching and whilst living in London (the world leading city of running to work), I thought what better time than now.

I'm running the London Marathon to raise money for Oxfam. They're working towards the goal of ending poverty for all. More specifically, they help out in areas of crisis such as Yemen and Syria, assist in developing areas by empowering women to become equal members of their communities and providing sanitary conditions as well as campaigning to challenge systems and create long lasting change.

Every donation makes a difference so thank you for your support in helping end the poverty cycle and giving those in need a fair chance.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for visiting my JustGiving page.

Despite some recent challenges, Oxfam is still carrying out amazing life-saving work, and that can only continue with the help of people like you. 

A great example of this is a story about Martha who lives in Nyal, South Sudan, which has seen a huge influx of people due to conflict forcing people to flee their homes. Martha is an experienced canoe driver, so was selected to be part of Oxfam's canoe voucher scheme. The scheme allows vulnerable people to travel and get around safely. Oxfam provide people with canoe vouchers which they can use to pay canoe drivers. The drivers are then reimbursed by Oxfam for the cost of the trip. Martha is well respected in her community and the scheme gives her extra income so she can cultivate her land and send her five daughters to school.

Countless more examples of the vital emergency and development work Oxfam are delivering around the world thanks to donations like yours can be found on their website.

The company I work for, Zurich Insurance, run a scheme whereby they will top up any donations raised by employees by an extra 50% - meaning any donations go that bit further.﻿

Thank you,

Rupert

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Last year I set myself the challenge of running two 10k's and a 20k for MacMillan. Due to health issues, I only completed half of the first 10k in March, managed to run the June one in good time but was not fit enough for the 20k. So this year I am taking it easy - 100k walk in under 30 hours. Then maybe I will re-visit the 20k, who knows!

The training has been fun so far but the 30hrs will be a challenge, so here is why I am doing it:

Oxfam has raised funds over the last 12 months which have:

- provided responses to climate changes for 85,000 people
- helped 350,000 people improve their crops, goods and services
- helped 2 million people get clean, safe water and sanitation
- helped 500,000 women increase their ownership of land/assets
- supported 9 million people in 31 humanitarian emergencies.

Funds from the walk also go to the Gurkha Welfare trust, which in 2016-17:
 - gave pensions to 6000 impoverished veterans or widows
 - hosted seven medical camps treating over 18,000 people
 - built/repaired schools for 40,000 children
 - piped drinking water to homes for over 20,000 people
 - built 1000 earthquake-resistant homes and repaired 300 more.

Thank you for your support.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hi everyone,

I'm putting myself through the punishment of running 26.2 Miles in the 2018 London Marathon. It will be exactly 10 years since I last ran the London Marathon and I'm curious to see the impact 10 years of a mostly horizontal lifestyle has had on my ability to finish this time. 

More importantly, I'm running for Oxfam, an organisation focused on the alleviation of global poverty, through coordinating global campaigns, humanitarian responses and long term programming. I have been lucky enough to work for Oxfam and see the phenomenal impact their work has. To continue their work, they are reliant on donations, so I really appreciate your generous support.

Cheers,

Mark

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hi!

Thanks for taking the time to read my page! 

This year I will be taking part in my first ever Marathon to help raise awareness and funds to tackle poverty across the globe.

Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn't inevitable. This is one of the main reasons I have decided to join Team Oxfam. They tackle a wide variety of issues ranging from inequality to child poverty.

More than 3 billion people live on less than £2 a day.

Over 700 million people don't have access to clean water.

Statistics like these scare me and it leads me to ask the question why have we let things get this bad? There have never been larger disparities in wealth than there is today and this is why I have taken on this challenge to help make a difference.

Over 20,000 children die every year due to poverty. 

On average for every £1 received by Oxfam, Oxfam invests 82p on their humanitarian, development and campaigning work. They also invest 8p to raise further funds, and a furthee 10p on support and running costs such as paying the salaries of staff who work all year round to deliver their work and who ensure they are effective and accountable.

Any donations would be much appreciated.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity. 


#TeamOxfam

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I signed up to the Edinburgh marathon earlier this year and was looking forward to a challenge in one of my favourite cities in the world. My friends then told me about the Hairy Haggis and pretty soon I found myself committing to a 5k, 10k, half marathon and full marathon all within the space of 2 days. It'll be my longest run yet and I'm going to need all the inspiration I can get to help me round!

Over the last few years I've become more involved with Oxfam both in terms of fund raising and filming projects for them and at every step I've been amazed by the work they do and ambitions they have to help people. 

Last year I took part in the 'Send my Friend to School' campaign. Along with 20 other charities they are aiming to get every child in the world into school by 2030. They already have great support from many countries and, even though the target now looks set to be realised by 2084 at the latest, it's still an incredible ambition. Before that I went with Oxfam to South Sudan and saw first hand the devastating effects of civil war over there. I also went to see their work in the Philippines in the aftermath of typhoon Hyaan, where they were on the ground rebuilding lives the day after the typhoon hit. 

It really is incredible work they do in so many areas, in so many countries, so any help you can give would be very much appreciated. It will also help reassure me that signing up to the Hairy Haggis was a good idea after all!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
My kids have been the biggest focus in my life over the last 9 years , particularly Sam who has needed me more than most. I Know from personal experience that life is not a level playing field. Many children and families have to cope with challenges and crises that make life hard.  

Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn't inevitable. They are responding to emergencies around the world right now, such as the crisis in Yemen, where millions of men, women and children are one step away from famine, and the Bangladesh Rohingya crisis, where hundreds of thousands of people are living in terrible conditions and need life-saving assistance now.  They are helping to empower women in their fight to end poverty and are helping to change the systems that deny people a fair chance to provide for their families.

Now my kids are a bit older I want to take on another challenge and in doing so support this really fantastic charity. Therefore on 22nd April I will be running 26.2 miles of the streets of London to raise money for Oxfam. Please help me help them by donating anything you can.

Thank you so much.

Cinders xx

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thank you for taking time to visit my JustGiving page.

Our wonderful friend, David had the privilege of serving with the Gurkhas, including some time living in Nepal.

The Gurkha Welfare Trust with Oxfam organise the Trailwalker 100 km across the South Downs. Our challenge, as a team of 4, is to complete the 100km (~63 miles) in less than 30 hours. In doing so we hope to raise as much as we can to invest back into the Gurkhas and into rebuilding Nepal, where they are still recovering from the 2015 earthquake.

So, thank you for anything that you can give us to inspire us through our 100km!

Best wishes

Rob & the team

Reach Out was written by Oxfam supporter Sarah Oxton, from Devon. It was professionally recorded by South West based singer - songwriter Andy Quick and his Plymouth based band 'The Unidentified Flying Orchestra'.
 

A suggested donation of £3 for the download would be greatly appreciated.

By Race Day 22nd April 2018, I will be 60 and this will be my first attempt at running a Marathon. I will be running with my wife Teresa...her first attempt as well! 

This is a massive personal challenge and we decided we would like to raise £4000 (£2000 each) to help Oxfam fight poverty all over the world. I have seen poverty at first hand through my work in delivering leadership training programmes in countries including Sierra Leone, Ghana, Libya and Morocco. We are so lucky to have been born into families free of poverty and we want to help others who cannot take for granted the things we have had through our lives. Things like food, water, heat, clothes and safety are a daily struggle for millions around the world. Even here in the UK, families live in poverty.

So as I run and as I struggle to keep going to the finish, I will be driven to carry on by remembering the faces and the families that I have seen living in abject poverty in some parts of our world.

Please donate as much as you can and watch out for updates as we train and prepare for the big day. We will be holding a Silent Disco here in East Devon soon and will publish details once we have confirmed the date.

Thank you

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Story

Hi Everyone,

Lets talk about a challenge!

On 15th July 2018, myself and three team mates will be walking 100 Kilometers to raise money and awareness for Oxfam UK and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. The Oxfam Trailwalker begins at Queen Elizabeth Country Park passes through stunning but challenging terrain of South Downs National Park and finishes at Brighton Racecourse.

Teams of four enter this event and have 30 hours to walk or run the 100 km trail, although our team is hoping to finish within 20 hours. It’s very likely that we’ll walk through the night (with little or no sleep) until the end. The event raises vital funds for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. The Gurkha welfare trust is a charity that provides financial, medical and community aid to ex-Gurkha servicemen and their communities in Nepal.

My team "GasPanic" is hoping to raise funds to help some of the world’s poorest people. Our fundraising campaign will also enable Oxfam to respond immediately to emergencies around the world, as well as to fight poverty at its roots by campaigning against injustice and empowering people with life-changing projects.

My Trailwalker team members and I will be going the distance and we hope that you can support us in this massive challenge. Please consider how you may be able to get behind us, either by donating us or sharing our journey with your contacts in social media. If you would like to support us then please find more information about our goals and activities on this page and where to donate for this good cause.

100 km is a long way to walk! But putting ourselves through months of intense training will be worth it for the impact our fundraising has on others through Oxfam & The Gurkha Welfare trust. Your support is what will take me and my teammates over that finish line.

We ask you to please give generously and consider that your donation will make a real difference.

Thank you!

Sushant

I have always had a strong passion to make positive impacts on the world that we live in and the people who live there - I have aimed to fulfil this by working on infrastructure projects in developing countries at work. While this has provided to be an exciting experience, I felt that I could do more by initiating something else on my own. The vision of Oxfam ("a just world without poverty") resonated with my inner motivations and fundraising for the organisation seemed just what I wanted to embark on as part of my resolution for 2018! 

Contributing through Oxfam has its own unique impacts, including making a sustainable impact on the people living in the poorest places in the world. This video is just an example of the difference Oxfam can make through its activities: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MTHfEwCjWJ8.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I've ran the Brighton marathon twice in the past (2015/2016) and have raised donations for different charities. This year is a little short notice but a friend has dropped out of the race and I've decided to run in his place and so with limited amount time of training, this year's race will be more of a challenge than ever.

In doing so, I have decided to run for Oxfam as it is a charity that makes an immediate difference to peoples lives.

Oxfam is well known for emergency responses to crisis that happens around the world. This includes the Syria , Yemen, Sudan, Africa, South asia that are currently undergoing crisis by helping out refugees with provision, shelter as well as mental and emotional support to families who have undergone traumas. 

They are also here for the long haul, helping out communities in out of reach areas to advance equal rights especially women. They also aim to build fair livelihoods in several countries undergoing poverty. 

As someone who's heritage is a country that has high rate and has personally witnessed poverty,  I can only imagine what these people are undergoing in their daily lives and so in some way, I'd like to help out in anyway I can.  I am quite grateful on where me and my family are right now and as a thank you, the least I can do is to give back to the people who have not been so fortunate no matter how small it may be and running the Brighton Marathon to raise some aid is a good start for me.

I don't expect everybody to have something to spare to donate but if you do, it will be greatly appreciated no matter the amount as this will lead us one step closer to minimising if not ending poverty and crisis across the world.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my fundraising page.


Next year I will be running my first marathon - The Virgin London Marathon, in April. After 12 half marathons I think it's finally time to take on the challenge of a full one!


The London Marathon is one of the biggest in the world and has been on my bucket list for years. I am delighted to be running to raise money for Oxfam, a charity I'm sure you are all aware of.


Oxfam is a movement of millions of people around the world, all working towards one simple goal - to end to poverty sooner.


They are committed to fighting poverty all over the world and any donations of any size are more than welcome. In our world of affluence over consumption it is crazy to think that around half of the world (over 3 billion people) live on less than $2.50 a day and 80% of the world lives on less than $10 a day - so please give what you can to support this amazing cause


Oxfam are currently responding to many emergencies around the world, including; 

Bangladesh Rohingya crisis - Hundreds of thousands of Rohingya people have crossed over to Bangladesh. They are living in terrible conditions and need life-saving assistance now, many are without shelter or clean water. Oxfam is responding now, providing clean water and other essential supplies.


Yemen crisis - Millions of men, women and children are one step away from famine in Yemen. They urgently need our help to feed families and save lives. A staggering 18.8 million people are in desperate need of help. Oxfam are supplying clean, safe water for drinking and washing.


So please please please donate whatever you can!


Cheers,

Kevin

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

8 years ago as I staggered over the finishing line at the London marathon, I swore "never again"! But here I am - because I believe so passionately in the work of Oxfam worldwide and because although I am a Curate (a trainee vicar) working and living in beautiful rural West Cornwall, I also have a very strong sense of being a Global Citizen: we - you and I - can make a real difference to the lives of those living in underprivileged parts of our world...in a world rich in natural resources, poverty shouldn't be inevitable. 

So, I have started again to run...my poor legs are getting used to a weekly Marathon Training Plan and we are now on target at 3.5 miles.  Selfishly, running helps me to feel more energised and more alive (and to cope with my mother's terminal illness) but much more importantly this marathon goal is my opportunity to not just "talk the talk" from the pulpit every week about justice, freedom and love towards one another but also to "walk the walk" or maybe it should be "run the run"!

So, please, let's reach out together to support Oxfam's work already touching the lives of over 15 million people in 55 countries: £13 will enable a female farmer in Rwanda to learn how to sell and grow better pineapple crops; £36 will feed a family of 6 in Gaza for a month through food or cash vouchers, and all donations will contribute directly to providing both emergency sanitation, water and healthcare in case of natural or manmade disaster, and just as importantly setting up long-term sustainable projects to enable our fellow citizens of the world to flourish.

In order to meet my goal of once more making it over the finishing line next April in my green and yellow Oxfam running vest, I will need to dig deep and aim high but it will all be worth it if together we can raise the £2,000 I need to take part and make a difference! 

Please join me!  Thank you :)
