charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Have any one of you ever asked what is the meaning of life? Why are we in this world or what our true purpose is? Past year or so I have struggled with an existential crisis and truth be told I am still not sure where I stand. But one thing I do know, there are people out there who are struggling just to survive and every one of us has a responsibility to help make a difference.
Running in the London Marathon has been a dream and bucket list item for a very long time. Getting the opportunity to finally take part and that to, on behalf of Oxfam has made it even special. Not only am I able to experience and take part in such a prestigious event but I will also have the chance to truly help the people who need our support.
Oxfam is one of the leading UK charities fighting global poverty. It is a globally renowned aid and development charity working and campaigning with partners in over 90 countries worldwide. One of my main reasons for choosing to support Oxfam was when I saw how extensively they were working in Bangladesh to help with the Rohingya Refugee Crisis.
Over half a million Rohingya refugees have crossed over to Bangladesh since August and this unprecedented number arriving in a very short space of time has caused a large scale and escalating humanitarian crisis. Oxfam has responded by providing water tanks, water treatment plants and containers for clean drinking water; portable toilets and sanitation facilities; 70 tons of flattened rice, 23 tons of sugar, and 23,000 fortified biscuit packs; plastic sheets for shelter, and other essential supplies; dignity kits with hygiene items for women, girls, and children. They have already reached out to 180,000 people and the only way they can do more is with our support.
Let us all do our bit and make a change! Come support me to reach my pledge of £2000 pounds which will go a long way in helping the people who are in desperate need of every penny that we can spare.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I’m so excited (and very nervous !!!) to have a place in the 2018 London Marathon on Sunday 22nd April! 

Oxfam is an amazing charity and all money raised will be donated to them!

 Oxfam works with others to overcome poverty, injustice and suffering around the world. You'll be helping to make that work possible.

Our work breaks down into three areas, all vital to achieving our aims.

Emergency response: we respond quickly to emergencies like the Ebola crisis: providing life-saving help like safe water and hygiene kits.

Development: we fund long-term work to help local people use their own ideas and skills: fighting poverty in their communities.

Campaigning: poverty isn't just about lack of resources: it's about bad decisions made by powerful people. Oxfam campaigns hard for real lasting change.

Please dig deep guys and donate what you can, I’ll keep you all updated with how the training is going !

Becky x

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hello!

I am running the London Marathon on 22nd April 2018 (my first marathon!) to raise awareness and funds for Oxfam. 

Many years ago, my grandfather got a job in Yemen to make a living to support his young family. The country my father was born in and spent his childhood in, is today in a major crisis. Luckily for me, he decided to migrate to the UK, where I have never felt a shortage of anything. However, there are still families and young children in Yemen and other poorer countries, who now need our help. 

Charities like Oxfam ensure that the suffering population have access to the basics of living, such as food and water. 

We live in a country and time where we take most things for granted, for example, clean water. However, there are millions of individuals suffering all over the world who would do anything for a glass of clean water, food, shelter, etc.


So, please dig deep into your pockets and use my page to donate, allowing someone less privileged to reach for that thirst quenching glass of clean water.

I will be following a training schedule to run the marathon however, your support is what will take me over that finish line.

Thank you for taking the time to read my story :)

Hani 


Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Oxfam
story: Oxfam is committed to eradicating poverty through a vast range of projects, whether it's dealing with an emergency crisis due to disaster or helping to build communities by providing access to clean drinking water and adequate sanitation. As a human being I feel I need to make my contribution in any way I can. I figured the best way is by doing something I love to raise money to support the wonderful projects they foster. I have run 5ks, I have run 10ks, I have run half-marathons but for Oxfam I had to do something  substantial, that would make me challenge myself; that would make me put the hardwork and hours in just like the wonderful volunteers at Oxfam do on the numerous projects they run globally! Hence I will be running the London Marathon in 2018 so that I can make my contribution that will help in the fight to end poverty, to build and support viable communities, to ensure the adequate use of land and water, and overall guarantee an equal and sustainable world!

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my page! 

This year I am running the London Marathon in support of Oxfam's work to reduce global inequality. 

A shortlist of the good and often unreported news of the past decade, and to highlight how charity organisations such as Oxfam support these.  

List of better news:

Source: World Health Organisation

  • Since 1998, absolute poverty* rates have dropped from 30 to 10%
  • Child vaccination rates from low income countries have risen from 50 to 80%
  • Since 1990, these developments have saved an estimated 110 million children’s lives

*Absolute poverty: living on less than 2$/day  (adjusted).

With your support we can continue to reduce absolute poverty and improve health equity.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
On Christmas day 2016, my family and I were sat down the dinner table pulling crackers. They weren't your standard crackers with jokes in, though. They had more challenging questions. One of those questions was: "What is on your bucket list?". I didn't even have to think to know that top of the list was to run the London Marathon!

Fast forward several months and I got a place to run for Oxfam!

I'm taking this very seriously. I've already started training, exploring the parks of London and improving my ParkRun PB! I've bought new trainers (to replace the previous pair bought in 2009) and a running watch is on its way. I may even be seen in running tights when it gets a bit colder!

I'm especially delighted to be selected to raise money for Oxfam as they're an organisation I've admired for a long time, even before I was thinking about having a career in international development myself.  Their valuable and life-changing work ranges from responding to natural disasters, to empowering people at the grassroots level, and from advancing women's rights to campaigning on inequality and climate change.

To learn more about Oxfam's work visit: http://www.oxfam.org.uk/what-we-do

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
﻿After attaining a Guinness World Record in 2015 for the fastest marathon dressed as an elf, I felt it was time for a new challenge! So... in April 2018 I will be pushing myself that bit further as I face the daunting task of running 3 marathons in just 15 days. On April 8th I will be taking part in the Greater Manchester Marathon and this will be followed by the Great Welsh Marathon on April 15th and the prestigious London Marathon on 22nd April.... boom!

I've never attempted anything like this before but I'm sure it is going to push my body towards its limit. Please give generously... Oxfam are working tirelessly to support those in desperate need and they can't do it without our help. Sadly, Oxfam have had a bad press recently and many have withdrawn their support. Those most affected by this will be some of the poorest people in the world so it is as important as ever that we raise as much as we can.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
About 1 billion people are still trapped in extreme poverty and many are especially vulnerable to the impact of climate change. With most experts forecasting slowing progress on reducing poverty, Oxfam provides vital help and asks some important questions.

Oxfam is supported by 30,000 volunteers operating in 90 countries. Last year it ran more than 172 programmes, responded to 31 emergencies and reached 11.6 million people with life changing support.

Having reflected on recent press coverage (and Oxfam’s plans in response) I want to ensure those that depend on Oxfam’s aid (as well as those volunteering and working for the charity) do not suffer from the actions of an unrepresentative minority.

I am therefore supporting Oxfam!

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We are Trekking 100km non stop across the South Downs in under 30 hours to help end poverty with Oxfam and the Ghurka Welfare Trust.

Oxfam works with others to overcome poverty, injustice and suffering around the world. You'll be helping to make that work possible. Our work breaks down into three overlapping areas, all of which are vital to achieving our aims.

The Gurkha Welfare Trust was founded in 1969, when it was realised that a great number of Gurkha soldiers and their families in Nepal faced destitution in their old age. Many of these soldiers had served alongside Britain in the Second World War and other conflicts; however they had not served the 15 years needed to qualify for an army pension.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thank you for visiting my fundraising page you lovely pineapples 🍍!

Despite the fact that I've never really run very far at all, am slower than a snail and also do a good impression of a running tomato everytime I attempt a jog, I've convinced myself that I can absolutely run the London Marathon. Yep, I'm a fool.

I am doing so for two very special charities, Oxfam and National Autistic Society.

I have been very lucky to work for Oxfam since 2010 and have been so lucky to see what a difference can be made. From supporting people to find decent work in the UK, to a village in Ghana where a project around maternal health meant no more babies died of preventable diseases, to seeing refugee children getting warm coats as they made their traumatic journey from their homes in Syria, I have seen so many times that a little can go a long way to helping people live safer, healthier and happier lives.

I have also chosen to support National Austic Society, who do amazing work to support those with autism and their families. I have a very inspiring sister who has worked with children with autistim for many years and have seen how important it is that children with autism get specialist support so they can also lead safer, healthier and happier lives.

I'm excited, nervous and everything in between. Bye bye toe nails, hello Lycra 👋

This is my first attempt at the London marathon and to be perfectly honest I’ve always been somewhat daunted at the prospect of running a marathon, 26.2 miles is a tough challenge both physically and mentally. However, I watched the 2017 London Marathon and I was simply awestruck by the incredible atmosphere and support from the public, I knew then that I had to try and be a part of the 2018 marathon. Luckily Oxfam accepted my application and I am immensely proud to represent a charity that makes a genuine difference to those less fortunate. Oxfam is tackling many global issues, from alleviating poverty to life-saving emergency responses, their work is absolutely critical so please help me reach my goal of raising £4000, any donation would mean so much. Thank you again for visiting my page.

story:
(You can follow my journey more closely on instagram, i’m ‘bluelauralove’)

Things i’m doing to raise money for Oxfam...

-you can sponsor me to cut my long hair off!

-you can sponsor me to run the 2018 London Marathon.

-you can buy jam and other home made produce from me. (Please don’t tick gift aid if this is why you are on this page!)

-you can buy a raffle ticket for the chance to win from an awesome selection of gifts donated post-Christmas plus from some incredible local businesses.

I used to volunteer in Colchesters Oxfam store. Oxfam are currently supporting the people Yemen through a very difficult time. I was lucky enough to visit Yemen when I was 21 and it was a beautiful country full of incredible people, customs, cuisine, architecture, and more. I have such fond memories of my stay there. Sadly due to political unrest the people are suffering terrible hardships that is just not being mentioned in our news coverage. Things have changed dramatically since my short stay there and life is now very difficult for these wonderful people. Please help me to help them.

story:
We have all been friends since we were members of Bristol University Officer Training Corps whilst at University and have been prone to doing silly things ever since.  We rarely catch up with each other these days with our hectic lives, and we thought it would be a good idea to combine a bit of a catch up with raising some money for charity...whether or not it is actually a good idea remains to be seen, but we are certainly going to raise some money for Oxfam; a very worthy cause.

We have so far conducted no training (unless dog walking / child raising counts), so will be relying on grit, determination and bloody-mindedness to carry us along the 100km route across the South Downs Way in under 24hrs.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hello.

You look lovely.

I know that times are tough. I know that there are lots of good causes. But if you could help me out I would be so grateful.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Yes that's right.......I am running another marathon. London 2017 was enormous fun, and with all of your previous kindness and generosity, I was able to raise £3000, but now its Brighton's turn to have my sweat flung in its general direction, witness my stumble-style warthog-like gait, hear my cramp induced profanity, and laugh at my pain as I pound my blistered feet into its tar-mac.

Please help me.

Any amount. Any amount. Any amount would be hugely appreciated.

Now it may have come to your attention that Oxfam is embroiled in a certain amount of controversy at the minute! My marathon place was secured a few weeks ago, before this current crisis erupted, and its dependent on my being able to raise a certain amount of money on their behalf. Therefore if you could separate whatever doubts and anger you may have about Oxfam's history and behaviour and accept that your money would go, not only, to helping them fix these present problems but also enable them to keep helping and supporting people across the world who are vulnerable, scared, and in need of help, I would be very grateful. 

As well as dealing with their current crisis they are also still fighting on behalf of some incredibly vulnerable people, providing; shelter, food and water to refugees fleeing war in Syria; medical supplies to victims of the Yemen airstrikes; fighting hunger and disease in drought affected Ethiopia, and also moving forward with their ongoing developmental work that helps the vulnerable  and poverty-stricken the world over.

Please help them help others.

I am also using this marathon as a training stepping stone to a greater challenge that will be attempted in June 2018; Ben Rand, my equal parts brilliant, equal parts insane, brother in law has persuaded me to join him on a pain-hunting adventure. We shall attempt to run the width of the country, in Hadrians Wall country, from Carlisle to Newcastle in 24 hours. 69 miles!!!!! A race called THE WALL. I genuinely think I may keel over somewhere in the vicinity of the A69.

Thanks for your time and thanks in advance for all your help.

Big Love

Philip

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I'll be walking 100km non-stop again this July in aid of Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust. The time limit is 30 hours, but last year my team of 3 completed in 22:06 despite the 10 hours of rain. This year, I want to do it better - better planning, better footwear, a bit more mentally prepared. About 12 hours in I did say that I would never do it again, that it was just a bit too much to push through, and then a blister popped and it was completely mind over matter. Somehow once you cool off and get some food and rest, you think, "I know what to do differently", and so you sign up again. This year, Oxfam needs a show of support too.

I've been a strong supporter of Oxfam since I was a teenager campaigning on the Oxfam Youth Board, campaigning and stewarding at festivals, and volunteering in a shop. I donate monthly and didn't stop doing so even when the media went crazy. Obviously you don't want your money to be going towards work and campaigns that are lead by inconceivably horrific staff, but you cannot contest that productive, life-changing and critical work is being conducted by the other Oxfam staff. They work here in the UK as well, battling at the root cause to fight poverty and tackle economic inequality to make lives just a tad better for those trapped in a vicious cycle. I found last year when asking for sponsorship that my non-British friends didn't quite know who or what Oxfam is, and so weren't up for donating. Now they will know who Oxfam are, but not for the right reasons...

While the money you donate will half go to Oxfam, the other half will go to the Gurkha Welfare Trust, a charity that helps support families of Gurkha veterans financially, medically and developmentally. The Gurkhas are Nepalese soldiers who were recruited in part by the British army due to their fearless attitude and sheer strength. The charity works in Nepal and the UK, and your donations are used as aid.

Be rest assured that your donations will go to superb causes, though if you're not bothered about that and would just like to sponsor me, then here's why: I broke my ankle 2 years ago and have pushed really hard to be stronger and fitter. 2017's Trailwalker was tough physically but I had worked hard to be ready for it. A year has gone by and I'm not sure I'm any fitter. Unfortunately, I had a mental breakdown caused by stress and anxiety, partly because of another injury that prevented me from exercising to my full potential. I had found that exercise and most notably running was significant in lessening my anxiety, and the achievements from pushing myself made me feel stronger mentally as well as physically. It's not a great thing to be motivated by goals as things can happen to stop you reaching them, but over the last 2 years I have learnt where my limits are and with every pitfall comes learning. I go into Trailwalker 2018 with experience and a more stable attitude. It still won't be made easier, and perhaps it will rain for 20 hours as opposed to 10, or perhaps it'll be exceedingly hot and we'll have to work as a team in a different way. My team Rich, Rachel and George are strong, motivated and have a desire to do this for the challenge - otherwise no way could the physical pain be a purely selfless act in raising donations.

Though last year I did a lot of mountain hiking, scrambling and trail running as training, this year I'm going more for endurance. I realise that I am pretty good at pushing myself, even with knockbacks, and so will be doing solo ultra long-distance walking and increasing my running distances. Where last year was about making up for missing out on mountain time, this year is about working towards a bigger picture and learning from experience. Trailwalker 2018 is part of that. While I can look at a 25 mile walk with no anxiety at all now, it is still tough - and so 62 miles non-stop is bloody tough, even though I've already done it.

If you like my story and are willing to sponsor me and therefore donate to the two charities I am fundraising for, then many many thanks.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Twelve fair weather walkers will be attempting to complete 100km of the South Downs Way,  walking through the night aiming to complete the challenge in around 24 hours. Battling against the elements, blisters and chaffing we will be putting our bodies through hell all in aid of a worthy cause. 

This challenge was chosen as one of the team worked with both charities following the 2015 earthquake in Nepal and witnessed first hand the incredible work that both charities achieved in the immediate aftermath of the earthquake. 

Any money that is raised will be used by both charities to tackle poverty throughout the world. 

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provides financial medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and wider communities. These veterans rely heavily on the Gurkha welfare trust for a pension that will allow them to live with dignity.

story:
Four people who have never before walked as a four. Two who are chronically unfit and one with a dodgy knee... the other one might be OK, but we'll be relying on him to get us through!

We're going to be walking 100km in a single stint to raise money for Oxfam. Through day and night, we'll be walking the South Downs Way which has the same ascent as Ben Nevis and Snowdon combined. 

Please do sponsor us for as much or as little as you can to help us reach £1,400.

Oxfam works with others to overcome poverty, injustice and suffering around the world. You'll be helping to make that work possible.

eventName: Sponsor me to get the Oxfam logo tattooed on my arm
story:
Hello! My name is Cathie, online I'm known as Lil' Miss. Geek Chic.

This year I am working with Oxfam as a marketing coordinator. Prior to taking on this role I didn't really know a lot about who Oxfam are and what they do, but since working with them I've learned a whole lot more about them, their work and the world.

I started to feel that what I was doing wasn't enough, I wanted to make a contribution to the organisation that would really make a difference... and then I had an idea.

What if I got the Oxfam logo permanently tattooed on my arm?! Well, I'm up for the commitment but I'm going to need some fantastic support from you guys to do it. You can read more about why I am doing this here: http://lilmissgeekchic.com/sponsor-me-to-get-tattooed-with-the-oxfam-logo/

So go on... give generously, you'll change a life.

Myself and 3 colleagues (Thorney Island AGC (SPS) Detachment) are attempting to run/walk 100 km in under 30 hrs across the Great South Downs (from the Queen Elizabeth Country Park to Brighton). All proceeds are to go to the Gurkha Welfare Trust. 

The longest distance I've ever completed is a Half Marathon (13.1 miles) and I'm not the fittest individual in the world either! So 100k (or 62.5 miles) is a massive challenge for me and the team, so we're certainly going to have to train hard for this one!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our just giving page.

At the end of last year we were looking to do a challenge that would genuinely be hard to complete and also hopefully fun at the same time. Maybe 20 years ago this would be something we could do far easier but given the gradient, distance, time requirements and injuries we all seem to be carrying it will be a challenge for us all. Doing it together will mean we will only fail to do this if a limb is falling off so even if it turns in to a war of attrition we will continue.

The event sponsor for this is Oxfam and obviously the press has not been great lately due to a stupid few. At first we thought long and hard about participation continuing (we signed up in Nov 2017) but the reality is the people in the wrong where not the people that need the help. As such after considerable research into what Oxfam actually do, we decided to continue our participation.

If you fancy helping 3 aging guys, who all have joint issues / muscle trouble or general issues,  try to achieve something and hopefully help a few people on the way it would be greatly appreciated. As well as the aging guys there is a small support team that we have and without their participation we could not do this. Arguably their task is harder given they are available for the duration of the event and are required to support us on the way so any sponsorship raised is also clearly their achievement as well. Also in the background their are people further supporting by looking after kids, animals and all manner of required help to give us the best chance of being successful.

Thanks for reading and if you want to know more just ask any of us and we will answer if we can.

Regards 

Pete, Lee, Rob - Participants

Leanne, Jo - Support Candidates

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
We are four young (ish), fit (ish) and fat (ish) men. We aren’t particularly athletic but have decided to walk a bit for charity. Well when we say a bit we are attempting to trek 100km (62 miles) across the South Downs in under 30 hours. It’s going to be tough but as a way to encourage us there will be a World Cup final and a few beers at the end of the road!

In return for our pain we are asking for donations towards Oxfam. The money we raise will help to provide live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterbourne disease. These kits will include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap.

Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Trailwalker is the challenge of a lifetime.  We will join more than 400 teams on a 100km race over the South Downs Way, from Portsmouth to Brighton on 13th-15th July 2018.  The money raised will be used by Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust to improve lives around the world.

Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal - an end to poverty to everyone. In over 70 years we've become world leaders in emergency water and sanitation, and experts in providing shelter, food and protection.

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provide financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the UK Gurkha Community.

If you'd prefer, you can always donate to our other incredibly worthy cause, Velindre Cancer Centre.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
So after having successfully completed the Saltmarsh 75 ultra-marathon last year and having said never again ... I find myself signed up and training ready to face yet another gruelling challenge! This time I'll be part of a team of 4 school Mums embarking on a crazy challenge, a 100km trek across the South Downs in under 30 hours. Starting at Queen Elizabeth Country Park, the Trailwalker route will take us along the South Downs Way to the finish line at Brighton Racecourse.

The money we are raising will be used by Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust to help improve lives around the world.

Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal - an end to poverty for everyone. In over 70 years they have become world leaders in emergency water and sanitation, and experts in providing shelter, food and protection.

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provide financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the UK Gurkha Community.

Any words of encouragement, support and donations will be very gratefully received.

Thank you,
Alix

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hello everyone,

Thank you for visiting my page.  On 13th - 15th July 2018 our team is taking part in the mammoth 100km Trailwaker.  As a part of the event we have also pledged to raise £1400 in charity for Oxfam.

It is more difficult to give money away intelligently than to earn it in first place.  The money we raise will provide live saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Nigeria from water-borne disease.  Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap.

"We make a living by what we get, but we make a life what we give".

Thank you

Sun

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Time to bring out my inner self i.e. Sir Mo Farah.

Will you help me beat my TRAILWALKER 2017 time of 17 hrs (and 9 minutes)... In order to facilitate this you will have to help me reach my target of given sum.

I am well aware of recent charity incidents that has tainted it's creditability however we cannot ignore the fact that there are still plenty of needy people who still requires vital support and help just for survival.

Some of my friend (plus my Wife) thinks I'm mad to go through same sweat and pain again but if my action and your contribution makes single person's life better or more worthy then throw me any challenge (no bungee jump, parachute etc), with your support and encouragement I believe I can take monstrous GODZILLA single hand.

Oxfam in Nepal: Oxfam's earthquake contingency plan was triggered and teams responded within 24 hours. Oxfam's earthquake response covers seven of the fourteen most affected districts: Gorkha, Nuwakot, Dhading, Sindhupalchowk, Kathmandu, Lalitpur, and Bhaktapur.

Established in 1969, Gurkha Welfare Trust provides financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities.

(PS, I promise to shout out your name as I go through various Check Points during the course of a race via FaceBook Live lol, to be precise there are 10 CPs in total.)

Thank you for your generosity and time.

Sunil Gurung

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Graham Willingale was many things to me; an extra Grandad, an inspiration, a mentor and most of all, a friend.His life was one which touched many and I feel lucky to say I knew him and have so many great memories with him. I savoured every moment.

Graham supported the Ghurkas for many years and when Adam asked me to get involved with this challenge, I was both honoured and excited. The challenge; my team (Adam, Dave and Charlie) and I shall run/walk/crawl 100km across the South Downs, finishing in Brighton. The record set by a Ghurka Regiment is 9 hours 50 min! Let’s see if we can do it in less than a day. 

Let’s go and make Graham proud.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Together with Julian, Nick and Chris I am taking part in Trailwalker 2018 trekking a mammoth 100km across the South Downs in under 30 hours to help raise money and end poverty with every step.

This will all be done in aid of Oxfam & The Gurkha Wellfare Trust. Oxfam works with others to overcome poverty, injustice and suffering around the world. You'll be helping to make that work possible. Our work breaks down into three overlapping areas, all of which are vital to achieving our aims.

Humanitarian response: We respond quickly to emergencies like the Ebola crisis - providing life-saving essentials like safe water and hygiene kits.

Development: We fund long-term work that allows local people to use their own ideas and skills to fight poverty in their communities.

Campaigning: Poverty isn't just about lack of resources; it's about bad decisions made by powerful people. Oxfam campaigns hard for real lasting change.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Running these 10km means a lot to me. It symbolically means giving a voice to all women on earth. To the one that can’t talk, to the one that won’t dare, to the one that have the courage to do so and deserve to be heard. Yes, I would like to run for us. Because we all matter, we all are unique and powerful. And Yes, it is  important to keep reminding it because words are power and behinds these words lies faith and conviction. Furthermore, we still live in a world where women have too little power given and are still diminished. How many times were women asked if there are (finally) in a relationship instead of being asked what were their dreams and aspirations? Not often enough. How many times were women reminded how important they are? I don’t know about you but it never happened to me. How many times were women truly allowed to express what they feel inside instead of being repressed? 

So, to all women that have lost faith in themselves, to all women that don’t trust their inner power, to all women that still feel repressed, I will run. I will run for us. I will run to get back what we have lost on the way, to be proud of who we are and to keep claiming equality. 

And when the race will be done? I will keep running, always, through my dreams, my aspirations, my words and actions. We will keep inspiring each other and keep working on reclaiming the respect we deserve. 

« Let women be provided with living strength of their own. Let them have the means to attack the world and wrest from it their own subsistence, and their dependence will be abolished. » Simone de Beauvoir. 

I also would like to share this TedTalk link called "We should all be feminist" that I found very inspiring. 

https://www.ted.com/talks/chimamanda_ngozi_adichie_we_should_all_be_feminists?language=fr

For everyone that would like to follow the Facebook page created "A Run for equality" where I put update on how the training is going, you just have to click on the link and like it :)

https://www.facebook.com/A-Run-For-Equality-2060427940841796/

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I plan to take on 100km of the South Downs with three
friends, it will test us all physically and mentally. We will re-think our
limits, surprise each other and we’ll help end poverty with every step.

Total ascent: 2,500m –  the equivalent of Ben Nevis  and Snowdon combined and  Distance: 100km – the equivalent  of 2.5 marathons, non-stop.

We’re not the fittest team to enter this challenge, and we certainly won’t be the fastest! But we aim to raise awareness for this cause and challenge ourselves in the process. None of us have ever attempted anything like this before, so please don’t think this will be a walk in the park. We aim to earn your donation! 

Right now the idea of hiking through the night non-stop seems impossible, but with your support and encouragement we hope to do you, ourselves, Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust proud. Whatever you can donate is appreciated.

When an emergency hits, Oxfam is there. At any given time, their teams are responding to an average of 25 emergencies worldwide. In 75 years they have become the world leaders in emergency water and sanitation,
and experts in providing shelter, food and protection. Support from people like you and me means they can do whatever it takes to help people not just survive, but rebuild their lives once the immediate danger has passed.

I aim to raise enough money so the Gurkha Welfare Trust can provide a complete diagnostic kit for a mobile doctor.

https://youtu.be/r8oHA2x45Dg

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
We’re not the fittest team to enter this challenge, and we certainly won’t be the fastest! But we aim to raise awareness for this cause and challenge ourselves in the process. None of us have ever attempted anything like this before, so please don’t think this will be a walk in the park. We aim to earn your donation! 

Right now the idea of hiking through the night non-stop seems impossible, but with your support and encouragement we hope to do you, ourselves, Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust proud. Whatever you can donate is appreciated. Read on to find out more about these worthy causes...

OXFAM IN ACTION
When an emergency hits, Oxfam is there. At any given time, our teams are responding to an average of 25 emergencies worldwide. In 75 years we’ve become world leaders in emergency water and sanitation, and experts in providing shelter, food and protection.
Support from people like you means we can do whatever
it takes to help people not just survive, but rebuild their lives once the immediate danger has passed. For example, after Hurricane Matthew hit Haiti in 2016, Oxfam got clean water running as quickly as possible to prevent the spread of dangerous disease. As well as distributing emergency tarpaulins and hygiene kits to keep people safe after the hurricane, we’re staying in Haiti until people can face the future with hope once more.
The Gurkha Welfare Trust in action
The Gurkhas are soldiers from Nepal who are recruited into the British Army. To this day, they remain renowned for their loyalty, professionalism and bravery.
The Gurkha Welfare Trust exists to ensure that Gurkha veterans, their widows and their wider communities are able to live their lives with dignity in Nepal. We achieve this primarily through the provision of financial, medical and community aid.
92 year-old Lalbahadur Pun has received a Welfare Pension from the Trust for 30 years. Lal now resides in our Residential Home in Pokhara where he often reminisces with his fellow Gurkhas and his experiences during World War Two.
“You found me in my village and gave me this pension, this home. You are repaying me for the risks we took and I am grateful.”

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our teams fundraising page.

The Trailwalker 2018 is taking place 13th -15th July. The challenge is to walk 100km (62miles) over the South Downs in under 30 hours. 

All of your generous donations will be divided up between Oxfam and The Ghurka Welfare Trust, both great charities.

Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal - an end to poverty to everyone. In over 70 years we've become world leaders in emergency water and sanitation, and experts in providing shelter, food and protection. 

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provide financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the UK Gurkha Community. The Ghurkas form an essential backbone of the UKs military capabilities and should be supported.

Each Trailwalker team pledges to raise £1,400 for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust as part of their challenge. Broken down between all 4 walking team members, this works out at £350 per person. We hope that with our help, you can smash the sponsorship goal!

The team have started training on a variety of terrains. It is important for us all to prepare both physically and mentally for the challenge - we need to be at a good level of fitness to ensure we can maintain a good pace up hills as well as on the flats. I will update the page on the different training we do over the next few months.

Thank you in advance for your support! 

To find out more about the challenge please visit - 

www.oxfam.org.uk/trailwalker

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thank you for visiting my page!

After ten years of running I thought it was time to finally attempt the full 26.2 miles, and I am combining it with raising money for Oxfam. They provide support to those living in extreme poverty, those impacted by natural disasters, and those living as refugees. They provide clean water and sanitation, help communities rebuild, fight for women's rights and challenge the systems that underlie poverty.

It means a lot to me that Oxfam and other charities are there to help when terrible things happen, so please do make a donation if you can. Donations will also help spur me on as I run (even more than music / cheering / high-fiving small children will) so I am super-grateful for anything you are able to give!

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

On 14th July 2018, our team of 4 have decided to set out on the crazy adventure of walking 100km (62.2miles...yes, really!!) across the South Downs as part of the Oxfam Trailwalker challenge. And all within 30 hours!

We will be starting from Queen Elizabeth Country Park near Petersfield and walking all the way to Brighton. The challenge is non-stop with the aim of completing in 30 hours. We will be walking through the day and night, no stopping to sleep. It will be hard enough staying awake that long let alone walking for the entirety!

We would really appreciate anything that you might be able to give, no matter how small, to get us towards our target of £1000 which will be used to help some amazing charitable causes for Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust. Your support really is what will get us through the aches and pains and inevitable breakdowns en route. Thank you so so much!!

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Pretty terrible news have recently come to light about Oxfam.

My view on it is that the top of the organisation has a lot to answer for, and that it's so frustrating to see the hard, dedicated, good work of so many being ruined by so few.

I'm still training to run the 2018 Brighton Marathon, and am hoping that any funds raised will still help tackle global poverty in some ways.

It's been 8 years since I ran my first (and only) marathon in 4 hours and 44 minutes. My goal is to beat that time, despite the added weight of these few years!

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
One day in January I went into work with one of the stupidest ideas I have ever had - walking 100km in less than 30 hours. How hard can it be right?! Turns out that this was one of those occasions where I am very WRONG!!!

Now we have found ourselves well and truly signed up - all because we get a curry and a medal!! Oh and because we are helping raise money... 

We may be the very few mad ones out there who are crazy enough to do this but please can you make all the blood, sweat and tears worth it and please please please help us and donate to raise money for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust (they are the ones making the curry apparently!!)

Thank you all for reading and I do hope you can donate even the smallest amount to help us get to our target of £1400 - even if it is just so you can laugh at us before, during and/or after.

Much love
'Scrambled Legs'
xxx

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
﻿﻿Four fit blokes required, no previous experience....

Challenge – ‘a call to someone or something to participate in a competitive situation or fight to decide who is superior in terms of ability or strength’

Well our challenge brings together a group of leaders in their professional field, who in truth know very little about one another. We will prove that with teamwork centered on a common goal, incredible things are possible.

The Challenge - Described as the UK's number one team endurance challenge, the Trailwalker is the ultimate team endurance event. From 13-15 July 2018, the challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km across the South Downs Way in under 30  hours in a team of four, with a support crew of two members to help you get to the finish line.

The Second Chargers Team

Buster Tolfree              United Trust Bank

Paul Stringer                 Norton Finance

Paul Ford                       Fluent Money

Jonathan White              Mortgage Brain ﻿

The Objective - The primary objective is to raise in excess of £4,000 for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust as part of our challenge. The Gurkha Welfare Trust provide
financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the UK Gurkha Community. 
Our other major objective is to complete the challenge as a team! 

Donate - Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thank you for your support

Buster, Paul, Paul and Jonathan﻿﻿

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

In Christmas of 2013 Foreign Concept, Stray and Xtrah got their heads  together and decided that rather than let some sought after unreleased music sit idle on their hard drives they would put it to use and offer people the chance to download the tracks whilst raising money for charity. 

This year Foreign Concept has gone one step further and we at Critical have all gone through the vaults and put an album together, again for a good cause. This time we have chosen Oxfam. Oxfam is a vibrant global movement of dedicated people fighting poverty. From saving lives and developing projects that put poor people in charge of their lives and livelihoods, to campaigning for change that lasts.

All monies go directly to the charity.  

Please give generously and enjoy the music!

Merry Christmas from all at Critical Music x

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Karuna Manor is the home of many powerful women and mothers. For International Women's Day, we want to help raise money for other women in India to make their lives better.

Asian Circle are currently working with the poorest indigenous tribal aborigine communities in Chhattisgarh and Odisha, East India, in partnership with Oxfam. The funds that we raise are being used to build shelters for women and provide counselling, sustenance and education programmes, in addition to working with the youth and men.

Here is what the money you raise can go towards:

£100 provides vital legal aid to 5 women

£300 provides a monthly counselling session for 20 women facing violence

£500 provide capacity building for women survivors, for example by establishing a survivors’ support network

£1000 could help cover the cost of awareness raising sessions for 100 men on violence against women, challenging entrenched attitudes and beliefs about women

£2000 could pay for 250 police officials to be educated about issues surrounding gender-based violence

£3900 would train 650 village women to form vigilance groups to support women facing violence 


So dig deep and help us to support women in India.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hello! Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

We are aiming to complete the Trailwalker 2018 in July to raise money for Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

Trailwalker 2018 is a 100km walk across the South Downs, which we have to complete in under 30 hours. We will be setting off on Saturday morning and walking all the way through to Sunday afternoon without sleeping. The distance equates to nearly two and a half marathons! 

Four of us will be walking together - Kayleigh, Charlotte, Kate and Frit - as team "Your Pace or Mine". We will be training from March and you can follow our adventures and updates on Instagram @yourpaceormine2018.

Please help us raise money and meet our target of £700 by donating to this page. Thank you so much! 

Kate and Frit xxxx
title: Kate and Frit - Your Pace or Mine - 100km Trailwalker

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks everyone for visiting our page. We are four independent, strong minded ladies, who got roped together over a conversation on WhatsApp one day, with the idea of tackling the Trailwalker 100km race, 'just for laughs'. I blame the gin for saying yes...

In addition, some of the team are also spending the months leading up to Trailwalker doing personal challenges too. For example, Sally is just about to have her super long blonde locks cut off (to raise money here and so she can donate her hair to the #LittlePrincessesTrust who make wigs for children with cancer) - Sarah is just under 500km into trying to walk 1,000km before Trailwalker - and Jodi is several races into the MuddyDog challenge, so you're not just sponsoring us for one thing - you're sponsoring us for several events!

We'll post details of our exploits here, but the big event is the Trailwalker Challenge itself on 14th July - can we walk 100km across the South Downs in under 30 hours? Hell yes, we can (we hope!) And certainly, if there's a whole heap of sponsors who would be disappointed, you can bet your bottom dollar that we won't be giving up til we've completed the challenge, or died trying.

We've set a steep target, but with four of us, we reckon we can reach it. You can donate in a lump, or given there are a few things we're doing together, you can always give us a few quid every time we post something. Even donating the price of a Starbucks or a pint will help this amazing charity do the work it needs to around the world, so please help us help them and get involved.

Help us to raise money and awareness for the Gurkha Welfare Trust who support those who fought during World War 2.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Rochelle - "Oi guys, don't you just hate poverty?"

All - "Yea!"

Rochelle - "Oi guys, don't you just hate running?"

All - "Yea!"

Rochelle - "Great, cos Oxfam have this fantastic 10k walk that we can do to raise money to fight against poverty."

All - "Just take our pledge money already!"


We are walking Oxfam's 10km ten times for a total of 100km. Our training has been rigorous, regimented, and consistent. We will be prepared. 

Join us and Oxfam on this walk on the fight against global poverty.
title: I thought it was 10k
pageSummary: We are walking 100km because poverty sucks and so does running.
pageSummaryWhy: poverty sucks and so does running.

Name: I thought it was 10k
ProfileWhy: poverty sucks and so does running.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
You can do it like an Egyptian, or in Memphis or you could
do it for 500 miles and then 500 more as a ludicrous display of affection...
but we're not that crazy!!! 

We will however be walking 100KM for charity in one(ish) day, no sleep, no secret taxis, no mercy. You may roll your eyes at mere walking but once you add in blisters, the torrential rain/blazing sunshine of July, searing bone and muscle pains AND Kimara’s tone deaf, incessant singing for 24 hours straight – you’ve got yourself a challenge!

We'd love for you to sponsor us so we can all help fund the
amazing work that Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust do and also so we feel contractually obliged to make it to the finish line.

Every little helps so if you can spare a few squid we'd be
very very grateful and we'll be sure to leave you alone on the Monday after the walk when we'll be in a lot of pain and the worst moods of our lives.

story:
Myself and 7 team members will trek 100km across the South Downs in under 30 hours and help end poverty with every step. Organised with the Queen's Gurkha Signals, Trailwalker is a unique opportunity to put our mind and body to the test.  Help us step in the right direction and raise money for a great cause “The Gurhka Welfare Trust's work “Established in 1969, The Gurkha Welfare Trust exists to ensure that Gurkha veterans, their widows, and their wider communities are able to live with dignity in Nepal. This is achieved primarily through the provision of financial, medical, and community aid.

Hi, thanks for taking the time to visit my Trailwalker 2018 JustGiving page.

The girls and I are undertaking the Trailwalker 2018 challenge, walking 100 kilometres along the South Downs Way in under 30 hours on 14-15 July 2018. Our support crew, which includes my lovely partner, John, will meet us at each of the 10 checkpoints to provide us with replenishments (edible or otherwise). Other than these 15-20 minute breaks at each checkpoint, the only rest we will be getting will be at the end of the challenge, 30 hours later. Stupid amounts of sleep deprivation, complete and utter exhaustion, and hopefully a MASSIVE sense of achievement - here we come!

Also, one of the best things about this challenge is that donations go to the wonderful Gurkha Welfare Trust (https://www.gwt.org.uk/), which  is close to my heart given my Indian heritage and India's close links with Nepal and the Gurkhas. So do please help us help the Gurkhas, one step at a time.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
﻿Thank you for visiting our fundraising page.

You may well be aware that The Tobys took on the gruelling trailwalker last year and completed the 100k walk in 26hours 26minutes.

We all agreed that it was one of the most challenging endurance events that we have undertaken testing us both physically and mentally.  To make the whole thing less bearable the relentless and torrential rain pouring down on us throughout the night made it even less fun.

Regardless, we raised an amazing amount of money for charity and despite saying that we would never do it again (which we filmed to remind ourselves) we couldn't resist the lure of the walking boots so here we are again.

If you can spare any money to support this fantastic cause please do donate, and thank you. ﻿﻿

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
As many of you will know, we completed the Trailwalker in 2017, and despite saying we would not do it again - as we endured some tough weather conditions - here we are once again, ready to tackle the 100km across the rolling hills of the South Downs. Hopefully we wont experience the monsoon of 2017, but we will be ready for anything.

Oxfam and the Ghurkha Welfare Trust are two amazing charities. But, they need our help if they are going to continue doing such great work. That's where you come in. We need your help in getting to our target and giving what we can to help those in need.

Any amount is greatly appreciated and will spur us on to complete the challenge within our target of 24 hours. We missed out by 2.5 hours last year, and so are more than determined to achieve it this year.

Thank you all very much.

charity.description: Imperial College London is a world leading, science based university, whose research explores the interface between science, medicine, engineering and management to deliver practical solutions.The Faculty of Medicine is a centre of excellence in research, development and teaching, and aims to improve patient care in associated NHS Trust hospitals.
charity.name: Imperial College
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

SCI needs as little as 50 pence per person per year to treat children and at risk adults for the neglected tropical diseases schistosomiasis and soil tranmitted helminths in Africa.

Treatment for schistosomiasis (SCH) and soil transmitted helminths (STH - whipworm, hookworm, roundworm), prevents anaemia, impaired growth and development in children and the development of life-threatening conditions of bladder cancer, kidney malfunction or liver and spleen damage.

SCI assists Ministries of Health across sub-Saharan Africa to control and then eliminate schistosomiasis and STH from their population utilising the World Health Organization’s Drug Donation Programme for praziquantel and albendazole. 230 million people, one-third of the total population of Africa, need a regular annual treatment of praziquantel, and 400 million people need a regular annual treatment of albendazole, to eliminate these parasitic diseases from their bodies (map – Distribution of NTDs in Africa).

SCI needs as little as 50 pence per person per year, to facilitate delivery of treatments in Africa.

Treating NTDs is a ‘best buy’ in public health according to The World Health Organization (WHO).

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
We are climbing to the summit of Africa’s greatest peak (all 5,895 meters/19,341 feet!) to raise funds to stop people going blind from avoidable causes such as Cataract, River Blindness and Trachoma.

We are climbing to the summit of Africa’s greatest peak (all 5,895 meters/19,341 feet!) to raise funds to stop people going blind from avoidable causes such as Cataract, River Blindness and Trachoma.

Having seen first-hand the impact of these devastating eye diseases and conditions through our work at Sightsavers, we decided to take on this gruelling challenge with our partner organisation, Standard Chartered. We thought that trekking for 7 days at high altitude, with only a month to train, would be a fitting way to show our dedication to the cause

There are 253 million visually impaired people worldwide yet 80% of blindness can be treated or prevented. Seeing is Believing (SiB) was launched in 2003 as an initiative of Standard Chartered Bank to prevent, treat and cure blindness across the globe. The Bank partnered with the International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness (IAPB) and leading international eye-care non-governmental organisations – including Sightsavers - to improve access to eye-care in communities where help is most needed.

Since starting in 2003, SiB projects have reached over 150.3 million people and helped prevent blindness by funding more than 160 eye-care projects in poor communities globally. The Bank has committed to raising USD100 million for SiB through fundraising and matching all public donations dollar for dollar.

Our international team comprises Bjorn, our Regional Finance Manager for East, Central and Southern Africa, Ziporah our Research Advisor  based in our Kenya office and Taome our Social Media Officer in our UK office

It costs very little to protect someone’s sight so, no matter how big or small, your donation will make a huge impact.

35p will treat or protect 1 person from blinding trachoma.

£8 will fund an operation to stop the pain and suffering of someone with advanced trachoma and save their sight.

£30 could pay for a sight-saving life-changing cataract operation.

£140 protects an entire community against the threat of trachoma.

All donations from UK residence will be kindly matched by the UK government from the 9 October 2017 to 9 January 2018!

All donations from UK residence will be kindly matched by the UK government

 
So please donate what you can to support our efforts. We would all be very grateful indeed for your support.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Hiii,

Those who know me already know my story for those who don't here it is....

I was diagnosed with right homonymous hemianopia when I was 19. This is a visual field loss on the same side of both eyes. In my case it was caused by a stroke. Dispite this happening I still finished college and continued working with the support of my family and friends. It has had a huge impact on my life, i won't ever be able to drive although before being diagnosed I wasn't aware of how serious my sight loss was I had taken lessons and failed my practical test 6 times! Yes how embarrassing lol. My stroke was a silent stroke it could have happened at any time. 6 years later leading us to now I have a heart monitor implant because I randomly black out. So this is just a little way of helping others.

Although my sight cannot be regained there are people who are struggling with sight loss daily who can actually be helped. 

All I ask is for people to donate as little as a £1 to help save someone's sight.  

£12 - could protect 35 families from river blindness a year!

 £28 - Could pay for a  cataract operation and give someone their sight back! 

£140 - Could treat and protect an entire village from trachoma! 

Just a few examples of what your money could be doing. If you wouldn't hesitate to help me if I could get my sight back please don't hesitate to help others. 

Thank you in advance for anyone that donates it means more than words can express.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder but what if the beholder didn't have sight!?

Without eyesight I can only imagine how someone would feel... Angry, Devastated, Afraid, Frustrated, Isolated, Alone, Different, Lost, Confused.... These are just a few of the many emotions blind people and their parents feel when their child is diagnosed with a lifelong eye condition.

The beauty of this world is felt by the heart but seen by eyes. I believe no-one should be denied this independence, this basic human sense or jewel of the body, if something can be done to rectify it.

“There are only two ways to live your life. One is as though nothing is a miracle. The other is as though everything is a miracle” and I believe that every dream can come true with hard work and determination. My name is Sehrish Zafar and I am an entertainment journalist and a TV Presenter. I understand it is not easy to encourage people to think optimistically, so that's where my charismatic personality and charm can help inspire people to make a difference in the society.

I am currently a freelance TV Presenter for various UK asian channels; I host at many stage events: fashion, charity, political and award ceremonies especially within our community. I am a graduate of BA Business Management and an award holder of 'Miss Perfect' at college.

Other achievements include fundraising for charities like Save the Children, Ucare Foundation; working as an Events Director of Pakistan Youth Foundation - Organised dinner events for Pakistani politicians, protests against Burma and Gaza Killings, promoted local community cultural music events, visited House of Commons and Pakistan High Commission on many occasions to support our community.

As I have selflessly helped support the dreams of others and those of my community, I hope I will continue to receive the help and support I seek to fundraise for those in need the most. I am fasting in aid of Sightsavers and your generous support in this great cause will aid me to do more for the ones who need the help most. 

 

Sightsavers believes that no one should be blind from avoidable causes, and that people’s whose sight can’t be saved should live with dignity and independence.

 

Did you know?

There are 39 million blind people in the world

80% of blindness can be prevented or cured

Around 90% of visually impaired people live in the world’s poorest countries

So the problems Sightsavers are trying to tackle are pretty enormous.

 

So please dig deep and donate now.

 

Thank you,

Sehrish

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
On 1st June 2018 I will be sitting off with my daughter, Olivia, to cycle from home, near Bristol, to Land's End and back. A distance of about 475 miles over 8 days. I am 61, Olivia is 22. In September last year I suffered a torn retina, which was repaired by wonderful staff at Bristol Eye Hospital. It gave me an insight into the devastating effect lose of vision can have on ones life. In January last year we had been on the Mekong river in Laos, we visited a village and saw a young boy who had a vision defect that resulted in him be excluded by his fellows and destined to a life of poverty, a simple operation would remedy that defect and allow him to lead a full active part as he grows up in his village. 

Sight Savers delivers that treatment to those like him and thousands of others.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

80 per cent of all blindness could be prevented or cured. It is a staggering statistic: that’s over 31 million people, most of whom live in the poorest countries in the world. And with poverty being both a cause and effect of blindness, a cycle is created that can be hard for communities to break out of.

Sightsavers wants to eliminate avoidable blindness and get equality for people with disabilities. They help blind people to see, prevent others from going blind unnecessarily, and support people to live independently if their sight loss can’t be undone.

The causes of avoidable blindness go further than eye disease, so Sightsavers doesn’t just slap a sticking-plaster on the problem – they campaign to make a fairer world and change lives for the long term, helping to eliminate avoidable blindness and get equality for people with disabilities. Help us to support Sightsavers in this incredible cause.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I’m running the Conakry 12km again but this year to raise money for equipment for the SOGUE (meaning “sun”) blind school in Conakry.  The school was founded in 2002 and has 45 children - 15 girls and 30 boys.  The funds raised will buy learning tools such as braille paper, slates, letters, styluses and cubarithmes. With these we hope to contribute a little more light to the lives of visually impaired children in this developing country.  

As ever I thought hard about  running the half marathon, but Conakry’s 30+ degree heat and high humidity beats me every time and I’ve decided that 12km is still my limit. 

I’ll be contributing through Sightsavers UK who have agreed to collect your contributions and donate them specifically to the SOGUE school. In Guinea Sightsavers are working on Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) some of which are diseases of the  eyes such as River Blindness. I know the Sightsavers team here well and am certain that they will squeeze the maximum value for the school from even the smallest amounts of support.  

Sightsavers UK’s overall mission is to eliminate avoidable blindness and promote equality of opportunity for people with disabilities, and they work in over 30 countries.  In 2017 they hit a record 1 billion NTD treatments  across the world - a phenomenal milestone.

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
As a general surgeon who has served in a Kenyan mission hospital I've witnessed first-hand the devastating damage that blindness can do to individuals and communities but also know how effective and cheap preventive and curative measures are. 

As CEO of Christian Medical Fellowship I'm deeply committed to healthcare in the developing world.

I turned 60 this February and am celebrating that by running to support this great charity. This will be my sixth London marathon since my wife and kids told me (with good justification) in my mid-40s that I was going to seed so I am indebted to them. 

In five previous marathons between 2004 and 2014  friends and colleagues have generously helped me to raise over £25,000 for Whizz Kidz, Alzheimer's Society, Down's Syndrome, Help the Hospices and Christian Blind Mission.  

Would you partner with me in raising another £5,000 to help Sightsavers protect and restore sight in developing world communities? 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Along with four great friends, all racing towards our forties, I have
taken the decision to run the Brighton Marathon and tick off a massive
challenge from my bucket list.

﻿I have decided to run the marathon for Sightsavers.  This is a
fantastic charity which was incredibly well publicised when I was a child, but less known today.  They work tirelessly to eliminate avoidable blindness and promote the rights of people with disabilities in less developed countries.

There are so many deserving charities, it was hard to choose who to support.  One of the main factors which helped me decide to run for this charity was that a family member used to work for Sightsavers.  Last year at the age of just 31 she was diagnosed with cancer and sadly passed away.  Please support Sight Savers in her memory and "live like CT".

I am not a runner.  I'm certainly not built for it, so please, please, please, dig deep and sponsor me for this great cause.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As many of you know I walked the 192 mile Coast to Coast path in September 2015 raising £2500 for Sightsavers.

I chose this charity as in 2015 I had laser eye surgery which meant I didn’t have to wear glasses anymore. I realised how lucky I was to have the choice and money to just make a decision and go to have the treatment unlike many others who have to live with their vision impairment.

When I read about A Million Miracles I felt the need to help as much as I could. Sightsavers work is very inspiring.

My Coast to Coast walk was an organised group that I joined with my friend Elizabeth. There were 14 of us in all and we soon became very good friends spending 14 days walking and chatting about anything and everything to while away the long hours across the Lake District, Yorkshire Dales and North York Moors. It was during these chats that 2 people, separate of each other suggested I take up running. I poo pooed them and said I had never even run across the road for a bus and there was no way I could go running but it stuck with me and I kept thinking about it.

When I got home I felt physically and mentally strong after walking 192 miles even though my feet felt like horse’s hooves.

I decided not to let the strength disappear and so I downloaded the app, Couch to 5K, and tentatively started the first 1 minute run that nearly killed me. Soon I was running a bit more every week and eventually I reached the 5K (30 minutes) and I cried. Not from pain but from the sense of achievement.

I quickly decided to down load the app 5k-10k and set off to double my distance over a period of months. Eventually cracking the 10K distance.

At this point I didn’t know if I should continue as I was worried I was too old and would destroy my knees. But my sensible head went out of the window as I downloaded the app 10K-21K and started to work towards the half marathon. I live in Ealing and there is a very good half marathon every year in September which goes right past the front of my house. I usually go out every year to clap the runners past, never dreaming that I would ever be able to do such a thing. (As of September 24th 2017 I have now completed that half marathon in 2 hours and 8 minutes and am very happy with that time for my first effort.)

I then received an email from Margaret (one of the ladies who was on the coast to Coast walk) to say that her friend Karen was going to be running in the London Marathon in April 2017 for charity and would we consider sponsoring her. Karen was very special to us, she was not just any old friend of Margaret, she went out of her way to drive across the UK with a box of homemade chocolate brownies and a bottle of fizz for us all on our last day. She met us in a small village about 2 hours walk from Robin Hood’s Bay (our final destination) with the brownies to share out amongst us to give us all a chocolate boost and then drove on to Robin Hood’s Bay with the fizz and shared it all out with a glass for each of us to celebrate our wonderful achievement as we dipped our toes in the water. What a wonderful friend.

Of course, I sponsored Karen, after all, one good turn deserves another even after one and a half years had gone by. I then spent all of Sunday morning trying to spot her on TV in the marathon. It was at this point that I decided I could do this. I could run that marathon too as I watched everyone running the course. So here I am with a place and am absolutely petrified, what have I done? But I WILL do this and hope to raise a good sum for Sightsavers and all those eyesights that will be restored to people who have lost hope.

I hated sports at school and was always useless. Sports day was my biggest nightmare as I ran around hurdles and under the high jump and would hide in the toilets. Who would think that in my 60th year I would attempt to do such a thing as run the London marathon? I wish my teachers could see me now.

Last year I ran in my first ever race, the Osterley 10K. it was 26 degrees that morning but I completed it in literally seconds over the hour and am now the proud owner of my first ever running medal. (I went to bed in it that night and woke up with the medal part under my armpit ) I have since hung it up to remind me of what i can achieve when I decide to do something. My Ealing Half marathon was run in 20 degrees and full sunshine but I completed it and now have a second medal which I also wore to bed that night!! I can feel a tradition starting here.

At the beginning of February I also completed, with a personal best of 57 minutes, the London Winter 10k run with 20,000 other people, starting in Trafalgar Square and running basically to St Paul's and back round the streets of London. It was freezing cold but so much fun and honestly, I felt like I would have liked to turn round and do it all again when I got to the end. I wanted to experience what it was like to run with so many people in London before the big MARATHON day.

If any of you want to support me on the day I am suggesting making a large banner of some kind with my name on it so I can see it and know where to look for you. I don't want to miss anyone that makes the effort to come out to give me encouragement. I have realised it's so hard to spot people in the crowd as I am running along.

I wrote a blog about my Coast to Coast walk if you want to read about my effort. How did I know that it would be the start of something much larger?

http://lozandherboots.blogspot.co.uk/
